note: While Forest Reserves and Protected Areas may be owned by stools (traditional authorities) or private persons, control & management is vested in Forestry Commission or other Government entities with powers that may practically truncate  ownership.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Communities made party to declaration of Protected Areas. Their rights may be sustained or extinguished on payment of compensation. Communities may manage State Forests and institute, own & manage Community Forests, and co-manage Wildlife Protected Areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The Amerindian Act provides that Amerindian Village may establish their village lands as part of a national protected areas system.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Article 101 of the Property Law grants indigenous communities rights to co-manage protected areas that are established within indigenous territories. But communities must respect the rules of land use that apply to protected areas. It is unclear whether IPs have full ownership rights in PAs.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Hungary that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory frameworks do not explicitly grant indigenous communities (Assyrians) land rights in Iraq

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Israel's laws do not directly uphold community land rights in formally protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Italy that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The law does not explicitly grant communities rights in protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Communities are firmly assured ownership and use of forests within customary lands and may create community protected forests but are only consulted in creation and regulation of National Forest and Wildlife Protected Areas, despiteunresolved overlap with customary lands.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Tribes are not recognized land or resource owners. A past right of members of communities who traditionally use forests to continue doing so for non-commercial purposes has been revoked.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Latvia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Macedonia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Communities may create PA governed by customary law and must be involved in state and private conservation initiatives. Constitution directive on community public domain implies separation of conservation status with tenure but undeveloped.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Community forests exist in some States, vested in Local Government Authorities. Only in Cross River State are access rights to PA granted to Community Based Forest Management Associations.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The State may designate communal property as protected areas, but indigenous communities may not be evicted from protected areas. While the government retains ultimate control and authority over protected areas, communities retain rights to manage land within protected areas. Article 59 of the 1999 Law on Protected Areas provides that "in the event that the lands [designated as protected areas] are of indigenous communities, the right of ownership thereof will be respected."

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The law is silent on whether Sami Population has rights to land in protected areas, but are entitled to compensation for loss of land if land is designated as a national park.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: While communities are not granted ownership rights in protected areas, the law provides rights to communities to manage land held within buffer zone areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The Reserves Act 1977 grants Maoris the right to take or kill birds and establish burial grounds within scenic reserves under certain circumstances. Maoris are also granted the right to establish agreements with the Crown for the purpose of protecting the environment and wildlife.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Pakistan's statutory laws do not explicitly recognize whether communities are granted rights in protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Article 13 of Act No. 72 of 2008 suggests that indigenous communities are granted the right to co-manage land within protected areas if the protected area overlaps with indigenous land. However, indigenous rights within protected areas are not clearly defined by Panamanian statutory and regulatory frameworks.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: National Parks Act, 1982 provides for the establishment of reserves, parks, and gardens, but only on state-owned land, and not on customary lands.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Poland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Portugal that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Paraguay's statutes and regulations do not explicitly recognize that indigenous community property includes rights in protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Romania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Protected Areas cannot be owned by communities, groups or individuals but if form legal entity may manage forest by agreement with Minister.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights in protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The coastal habitat upon which the Seletar rely continues to shrink, due to development. What remains is terribly polluted.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Mixed: for Forest Reserves, provision made for rights to be sustained or compensated for if extinguished, or Community Forests created. Much less provision in wildlife sector, consultation with chiefdom councils only required for Strict Nature Reserves.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Slovakia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The Laponia World Heritage site is a protected area, and the Sami have a right to co-manage land and water held within this protected area. However, these rights do not apply to other protected areas outside of Laponia.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Syria's laws do not explicitly uphold community land rights in formally protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Tajikistan that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights in protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The law explicitly allows for communal ownership of protected areas that are not considered part of the public domain of the state. However, the national legislation still misses a clear definition of public domain of the state. Furthermore, the classification as protected area gives the state the right to expropriate the areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The law does not explicitly establish that communites have rights in protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Ukraine that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The law establishes that protected natural areas should be included in the titling of indigenous lands, but the procedures for implementing this provision are not entirely clear.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: The law does not explicitly grant communities rights in protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Yemen's laws do not directly uphold community land rights in formally protected areas.

indicatorLabel: X - Land Rights in protected areas - Indigenous People
note: Any land may be subject to restitution orders including Protected Areas. Provision for this in National Forests Act. PA may only be declared on community land with its consent.

I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Unequal status with private rights. Security only through issue of formal right and which excludes most rangeland and all forest. Title is positively without transformation into non-customary form.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Laws recognise unregistered customary rights as legitimate rights of possession with equity with non-customary rights but no statement as to whether requires formalization (certificate) for full equity.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: PIOC, ICO, and PC are recognized by the Constitution. Their customary rights on the land are recognized, protected, and guaranteed. Recognition of legal standing exists but in practice there are certain limitations for the exercise of their rights

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Areas occupied by the remnants of the Quilombo communities are recognized. Definitive ownership, demarcation, and titling are stated as the government's duty.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Positive early legal attempt(1968) to secure customary rights but flawed; e.g. law vests title in Boards, not in communities; no recognition of collective ownership; customary rights definitively use rights not ownership. .

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Communities recognized are indigenous, black, afrocolombian, 'raizales' and 'palenqueras'. Collective property is recognized over areas customarily occupied.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: To obtain equal tenure security with private land (melk) agro-pastoral groups must form legal entities and demonstrate development of arable lands. Certificate of Possession can then be converted into Certificate of Ownership.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: A level playing field in that while state owns all land, citizens equally eligible for lifetime usufruct for houses & arable farms. No provision for communal agro-pastoral or pastoral tenure, although local access definable on village area basis.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Community land is a subject-matter which is not recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Communities can form rural forest institutions, collectives or partnerships, and manage/ utilize exploitation rights/ business licenses to forest resources; however the law does not grant communities a proprietary right to the forest area.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Under the FRA 2006, Scheduled Tribes and other traditional forest dwellers are granted the right to hold and live in forest land. However, these rights do not extend beyond forest lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Federal legislation only provides for government and private ownership rights. The laws are silent on community land rights.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Constitution & Land Act provide for community land as one of three landholding classes with equal force & effect. Customary rights also given equal recognition & protection with freehold & leasehold rights.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Unstated but implied equivalency of customary rights with leases given high status of customary rights to land (land owned by nation). Limited provision for other than for registered entities to own rights in common.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Ejidos land is divided into three classifications, and the degree of ownership and management depends on the classification, but the law provides for ownership of ejido lands. However, ownership is vested in assemblies.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law only allocates private ownership of land to citizens-families for family needs, agriculture purposes or other purposes, but herders are allocated possession contracts to pastureland.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Recognizes customary lands but as permissive occupation as governed by traditional authorities & customary law. Land law vests customary land in the President, empowers Minister to declare by notice as public land or to privatize for agricultural development purposes.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Communal lands vested in Government, allowing customary owners to register customary use right to the land only. Unequal as freehold rights are vested in citizens not state. Poor provision for collective rights. Law firmly focused on individuals.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Recognized communities: coastal peasant communities, sierra peasant communities, and native communities of the jungle (Law 26505 Art. 10). They are recognized as entities under the law with guaranteed property rights over their lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Since 1970  customary rights reduced to occupancy on Government property, but with potential to register usufruct rights. No progress on commitments of 2005 Peace Agreement &  2005 Constitution to remedy.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Constitution provides for community land  with private & public land. Land Act stipulates customary rights including those held in common have equal force as freehold or leasehold rights. Recognition of community lands a key principle.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Strong legal equivalency for customary law affecting c.54% of land with Roman Dutch Common Law provisions affecting Title Deed Land (46%). Main limitations are King's extreme authority & lack of guiding statutes for customary tenure.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Customary rights are permissive occupancy on state lands and with no distinction between customary property and wastelands (terres sans ma√Ætres).

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The Constitution establishes that communities shall have the right to participate in the management, maintenance and exploitation of natural resources. Community Land Use Permits granted since 2011, but no community ownership rights are granted.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Law explicit that lawful occupation of land either granted by the state or under customary tenure 'shall be deemed to be property', and that a granted and customary right have the same legal status and effect.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Land vested in citizens. Customary tenure accorded equivalent legal force & effect as freehold, leasehold and mailo tenure systems.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Customary land explicitly provided for, recognized as existing and protected. However, defined as a right of use and occupation under customary law, not ownership and unable to be formalized in a title.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Customary rights defined as occupation and use rights only, land itself is vested in President, governed by him and District Councils with absolute powers, but with admission of customary law and powers of appointed traditional authorities in allocation.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law states that the Aland Islands are autonomous and the Aland Parliament shall represent the people of the Aland Islands in matters relating to its autonomy. However, ownership rights are limited to the Aland Islands and not other parts of Finland and decision-making power is granted to the Aland Parliament.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Austria's federal skeletal law (corridor constitutional principle 1951) establishes rights to common property, but the details of these rights are established through state-level legislation (LandMark's legal assessment, however, is limited to federal legislation). Communities with rights over common pasture land are organized as corporations.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The national level law does not explicitly grant rural communities rights to community forests in Bulgaria. Control and management of community forests is vested in municipalities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of rural communities in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: State-level (cantonal) laws recognize community rights to "Group inherited" forests and common pastures (e.g. Canton Graub√ºnden). However, since LandMark's assessment is limited to national level laws, state-level laws are not assessed. There are no explicit provisions recognizing and protecting community land rights in federal laws.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The Law No. 5 on Agricultural Communities 1968 (Amended 1993) provides communities with rights to own, use and enjoy lands held in common. However, the law establishes limitations on these ownership rights and it is unclear whether communities can use these lands for non-agricultural purpose.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law grants ownership of collectively-owned lands, forests, mountains, grasslands, unclaimed land, beaches to all members of the village collectives.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Community/ customary lands recognized as existing but denied status as property until certificated and then Certificates converted into property titles. Opportunity to do so lasts only till 2019 at which point the customary domain ceases to exist.  Almost no uptake of certification or conversionary titling.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Constitution implies recognition of property acquired in accordance with custom and land law recognizes pre-existing customary rights but same law also suggests formal entitlement is necessary to be protected.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Decree No. 125 establishes that agricultural cooperatives are granted use rights to agricultural land for purposes of conducting agricultural production activities. The state retains ownership rights over agricultural land. Article 19 of the Constitution provides that "Small farmers, with prior authorization from the competent State agency, and in compliance with the other legal requirements, may incorporate their land only into agricultural-livestock cooperatives of production. They also may sell, exchange, or transfer it, through another title, to the State and to agricultural-livestock production cooperatives, or to small farmers, in the instances, forms and conditions that the law establishes without prejudice to the State's preferential right to its purchase, through payment of its fair price".

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The Federal Forest Act recognizes ownership rights to community forests. These "community forests" are set up like private corporations (associations) for purposes of forestry production and sale. "Forstbetriebsgemeinschaften" community forests are also recognized by the Federal Forest Act (Sec. 16).

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The 2008 Constitution establishes that Indigenous communes, communities, peoples and nations are recognized and guaranteed protection.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: According to a secondary source (see comments box), some privately owned forests in Spain are held and managed collectively in practice. However, the national law on Forests (Law No. 43/2004) does not explicitly grant communities rights to forest lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Customary/ community based rights recognized only obliquely. Individual holding rights for farms and houses acquired through direct  state allocation. Weak provision for communal holdings. Neither are equivalent in security to leaseholds.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law states that the Aland Islands are autonomous and the Aland Parliament shall represent the people of the Aland Islands in matters relating to its autonomy. However, ownership rights are limited to the Aland Islands and not other parts of Finland and decision-making power is granted to the Aland Parliament.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Only registered lands are deemed to be property, the rest is State property. No provision for customary rights to be registered. Unregistered homesteads in recognized settlements enjoy lawful possession. Most land area of communities is outside these.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Customary lands constitutionally recognized as lawfully owned and lawfully governed by customary authorities and cannot be alienated into statutory freehold tenure.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Strong support for customary rights but with limitations, mainly the fact that the State may declare any regions' lands (customary land) state property, distinct from compulsory acquisition processes.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The Forest Rights Act grants communities the right to enter into community forest management agreements (CFMAs), but the procedures are not yet established in regulations

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulator framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Hungary.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Collectives in Iraq are granted possession rights to agricultural units for purposes of establishing a collective farm. Collectives are also granted compensation in case their land is requisitioned. However, the Agrarian Reform Authority retains broad authority over these lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Communal land is not recognized in any of the Israeli laws assessed. The Israel Land Administration [ILA] manages approximately 93% of Israel's land. The remaining 7% of land is either privately owned or under the protection of religious authorities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: National-level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous or local communities. However, collective property rights of rural communities in Northern Italy are recognized by state-level laws in Trentino.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Jamaica's statutory and regulatory frameworks do not recognize the land rights of the Maroons and has not accepted or rejected the treaty between the Maroons and Great Britain

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Local communities are granted the right to form Pasture User Unions, but communities are only granted use rights to pasture; pastures are owned by the state. Pasture User Unions represent the interests of livestock owners and pasture users.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The Forestry Law (2002) recognizes the traditional user rights of local communities living within Permanent Forest Reserves. Communities can also establish Community Forest Agreements under Article 44 of the Law on Forestry.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The Land Law 2003 and implementing decrees recognize use rights to collectively and customarily held land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Ambivalent status: Policy recognises customary rights including communal holdings as property, registered or not, but not yet entrenched in land law. Forest law does however recognise community forestlands as owned,  the major communal resource.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law does not recognize the rights that tribes exercise over land as lawful forms of ownership. Law No. 7/1986 deems all land in Libya unowned and limits registration to developments on the land (house, etc.) within limits of owning one plot, premise, or farm.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Latvia.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights in Macedonia.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: While State owns the soil, communities & their members own rights to the land in accordance with custom or by occupation in good faith and may register these rights as DUATS with equivalent force to DUATS not acquired on basis of custom or occupation.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: While all land is vested in State Governors or Local Government Authorities (LGA) as trustees, customary right holders are assumed to be lawful possessors without certificates.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Indigenous communities in Nicaragua are granted ownership rights that are recognized and protected by the 1987 Constitution. The Statute Autonomy of the Atlantic Coast (187) and the Communal Land Law(2003) provide indigenous peoples with the right to own and use communal lands based on their traditional and customary patterns of land and resource use and occupancy.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law grants communities the rights use Bygd commons for agricultural purposes. Bygd commons are defined as "community-owned commons (as opposed to state-owned) where farmers living in a ‚Äúbygd" have certain use rights (profits) tied to their cadastral farm units (rights of common appendant) such as fishing, grazing, logging, etc.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Land is divided into three tenure types: state land, private land, and Guthi (religious) land. Communities are granted user rights to forests, but the state retains broad power to extinguish forest areas collectively held and used by communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The Constitution recognizes customary law and the Federally Administered Tribal Areas, which follow customary tenure systems (Pashtunwali) and provide for collective tenure and community based land governance by villages, clans and shura.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law provides clear ownership rights to communities that hold customary land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The national level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of local communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Law No. 68/93 (Law on Baldios) states that vacant land (wasteland) in Portugal is owned and managed by local communities (Art. 1). However, communities must abide by use plans that are developed in cooperation with Portuguese administrative bodies (Art. 6).

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law provides for community ownership rights to forest lands (Art. 92, Forest Code, 2008). However, communities must form an association to obtain these rights (Arts. 93-95, Forest Code, 2008).

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Although most recognized parcels have roots in customary ownership the customary regime is extinguished at registration. Many rights curtailed including to common lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Since 1927 customary rights accorded full legal support as owned lands, vested in Tribal Authorities (TA) as trustees for communities. TA govern lands by customary law, which is given full constitutional support as the applicable law in 85% of country.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law grants communities rights to "community forests" which are defined as property belonging to many owners that cannot be divided because the forests are supposed to be managed as a whole. However, there are no explicit community rights to other commons aside from forest lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory legal frameworks do not recognize land rights held by indigenous or local communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Pastures are state property in Tajikistan. However, local communities can obtain rights to use pastures under short-term leases if the community obtains a certificate signifying the Pasture User Union is registered.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The law establishes that 'community property is the land that it is used in common by a community, according to their customary practices'. There is no restriction to the type of property that can be owned by a community.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Article 4 of the Law on Pastures, 1998 provides that villages have right to use rangelands, pastures and winter pastrues.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Articles 142-143 of the Constitution recognize community property rights. Article 83 of the 2001 Land Code and Article 9 of the 1994 Forest Code recognize communal ownership rights to land and forests in Ukraine. Article 56 of 2009 the Land Code provides that  forest lands are held in state, communal and private property.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Communities may only be allocated land use rights through certificates. The State retains broad authority to recover land use rights granted to communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Yemen's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights. Yemen's State Land Authority estimates that 90 percent of all land in Yemen is state owned.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Community Lands
note: Customary land is vested in the State or in the Ingonyama Trust in KawZulu Natal. Nevertheless rights protected as if property.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Unequal status with private rights. Security only through issue of formal right and which excludes most rangeland and all forest. Title is positively without transformation into non-customary form.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution "empowers Congress to" respect and protect indigenous community land rights, but this provision has not been implemented by federal legislation.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The High Court of Australia recognized indigenous communities  have rights to their land. Native is a bundle of rights and not akin to freehold title. Exactly what rights native title amounts to depends on the nature of the indigenous group's customary use of the land. The fact that native title can be extinguished or suppressed through certain acts further weakens the legal status. But Government retains right to extinguish native titles under the Native Title Act 1993.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Laws recognise unregistered customary rights as legitimate rights of possession with equity with non-customary rights but no statement as to whether requires formalization (certificate) for full equity.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: PIOC, ICO, and PC are recognized by the Constitution. Their customary rights on the land are recognized, protected, and guaranteed. Recognition of legal standing exists but in practice there are certain limitations for the exercise of their rights

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution recognizes possession rights to the lands traditionally occupied. This includes lands where communities live on a permanent basis, those used for productive activities, and those necessary to protect communities' well being.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Positive early legal attempt(1968) to secure customary rights but flawed; e.g. law vests title in Boards, not in communities; no recognition of collective ownership; customary rights definitively use rights not ownership. .

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Supreme Court, the Constitution Act, 1982, and the Indian Act recognize aboriginal land rights (aboriginal title). But State retains underlying ownership, aboriginal title is a right to occupy and use lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Communities recognized are indigenous, black, afrocolombian, 'raizales' and 'palenqueras'. Collective property is recognized over areas customarily occupied.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: To obtain equal tenure security with private land (melk) agro-pastoral groups must form legal entities and demonstrate development of arable lands. Certificate of Possession can then be converted into Certificate of Ownership.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: A level playing field in that while state owns all land, citizens equally eligible for lifetime usufruct for houses & arable farms. No provision for communal agro-pastoral or pastoral tenure, although local access definable on village area basis.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous land rights are not explicitly recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Basic Agrarian Law recognizes "evidently still existent" (adat- customary) land rights. The Constitutional Court recognized indigenous peoples as owners of customary forests. The state can convert customary forests to state forest.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Under the FRA 2006, Scheduled Tribes and other traditional forest dwellers are granted the right to hold and live in forest land. However, these rights do not extend beyond forest lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Constitution & Land Act provide for community land as one of three landholding classes with equal force & effect. Customary rights also given equal recognition & protection with freehold & leasehold rights.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Ownership of indigenous community lands are granted by the State to indigenous communities as collective ownership. Collective ownership right limited to cultivated/shifting cultiv. lands, burial land, spiritual forest land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Unstated but implied equivalency of customary rights with leases given high status of customary rights to land (land owned by nation). Limited provision for other than for registered entities to own rights in common.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Comunidades are classified as either common land or human settlement land, and legally all members of the comunidad are considered to have equal ownership claims in the land. Unlike ejido land, there is no explicit right to alienate comunidad land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The law only allocates private ownership of land to citizens-families for family needs, agriculture purposes or other purposes, but herders are allocated possession contracts to pastureland.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Recognizes customary lands but as permissive occupation as governed by traditional authorities & customary law. Land law vests customary land in the President, empowers Minister to declare by notice as public land or to privatize for agricultural development purposes.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Federal Court and High Court of Malaysia recognized that indigenous communities have a proprietary interest in their ancestral lands. However, there is no federal statute which recognizes indigenous/ community land rights.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Communal lands vested in Government, allowing customary owners to register customary use right to the land only. Unequal as freehold rights are vested in citizens not state. Poor provision for collective rights. Law firmly focused on individuals.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Recognized communities: coastal peasant communities, sierra peasant communities, and native communities of the jungle (Law 26505 Art. 10). They are recognized as entities under the law with guaranteed property rights over their lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Right of ownership by ICCs/IPs to ancestral domains and lands explicitly recognized. Expansive definition of ancestral domains, including the commonage, even if no longer exclusively occupied by ICCs/IPs.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Federal legislation grants indigenous communities the right to freely use land and renewable natural resources in their traditionally occupied territories. Law No. 104-FS grants indigenous peoples ""Territories of Traditional Natural Use"".

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Since 1970  customary rights reduced to occupancy on Government property, but with potential to register usufruct rights. No progress on commitments of 2005 Peace Agreement &  2005 Constitution to remedy.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Constitution provides for community land  with private & public land. Land Act stipulates customary rights including those held in common have equal force as freehold or leasehold rights. Recognition of community lands a key principle.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Strong legal equivalency for customary law affecting c.54% of land with Roman Dutch Common Law provisions affecting Title Deed Land (46%). Main limitations are King's extreme authority & lack of guiding statutes for customary tenure.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Customary rights are permissive occupancy on state lands and with no distinction between customary property and wastelands (terres sans ma√Ætres).

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution establishes that communities shall have the right to participate in the management, maintenance and exploitation of natural resources. Community Land Use Permits granted since 2011, but no community ownership rights are granted.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Law explicit that lawful occupation of land either granted by the state or under customary tenure 'shall be deemed to be property', and that a granted and customary right have the same legal status and effect.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Land vested in citizens. Customary tenure accorded equivalent legal force & effect as freehold, leasehold and mailo tenure systems.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Native American legal rights to land may be established by aboriginal possession, by treaty, by act of Congress, by executive action, by purchase, or by action of states. But the gov't retains broad power to expropriate.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Customary land explicitly provided for, recognized as existing and protected. However, defined as a right of use and occupation under customary law, not ownership and unable to be formalized in a title.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Customary rights defined as occupation and use rights only, land itself is vested in President, governed by him and District Councils with absolute powers, but with admission of customary law and powers of appointed traditional authorities in allocation.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Austria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Bulgaria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher found no evidence of indigenous community land in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Switzerland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous communities are recognized by Law 19253 as the legal owners of their land (art. 12). However, these rights are subject to certain limitations, such as approval by the National Indigenous Development Corporation on matters relating to registration.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The law grants ownership of collectively-owned lands, forests, mountains, grasslands, unclaimed land, beaches to all members of the village collectives.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Community/ customary lands recognized as existing but denied status as property until certificated and then Certificates converted into property titles. Opportunity to do so lasts only till 2019 at which point the customary domain ceases to exist.  Almost no uptake of certification or conversionary titling.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: A special law on IP (2011) recognizes that IP exist, protects their property rights, and acknowledges that the population sustain those rights in the absence of registration. However, no law has been enacted to apply this framework law.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Law No. 6172 provides that indigenous communities are the owners of land held within their territories (Art. 2).

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The law does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous peoples in Cuba.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The 2008 Constitution establishes that Indigenous communes, communities, peoples and nations are recognized and guaranteed protection.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Spain that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Customary/ community based rights recognized only obliquely. Individual holding rights for farms and houses acquired through direct  state allocation. Weak provision for communal holdings. Neither are equivalent in security to leaseholds.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Finland's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize and protect the land rights of Sami populations in Finland.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Only registered lands are deemed to be property, the rest is State property. No provision for customary rights to be registered. Unregistered homesteads in recognized settlements enjoy lawful possession. Most land area of communities is outside these.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Customary lands constitutionally recognized as lawfully owned and lawfully governed by customary authorities and cannot be alienated into statutory freehold tenure.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Strong support for customary rights but with limitations, mainly the fact that the State may declare any regions' lands (customary land) state property, distinct from compulsory acquisition processes.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Under the State Lands Act, 1910, President may issue land titles to Amerindian communities. By doing so, statutory ownership rights are transferred to the Amerindian Community. The Amerindian Act 2006 recognizes the traditional ownership rights of Amerindian villages and communities, but these communities are not given the right to exclude others from their lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The 2004 Property Law recognizes the ownership rights of  indigenous peoples and Afro-Hondurans.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Hungary that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory frameworks do not explicitly grant indigenous communities (Assyrians) land rights in Iraq

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Communal land is not recognized in any of the Israeli laws assessed. The Israel Land Administration [ILA] manages approximately 93% of Israel's land. The remaining 7% of land is either privately owned or under the protection of religious authorities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Italy that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Land Law 2003 and implementing decrees recognize use rights to collectively and customarily held land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Ambivalent status: Policy recognises customary rights including communal holdings as property, registered or not, but not yet entrenched in land law. Forest law does however recognise community forestlands as owned,  the major communal resource.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The law does not recognize the rights that tribes exercise over land as lawful forms of ownership. Law No. 7/1986 deems all land in Libya unowned and limits registration to developments on the land (house, etc.) within limits of owning one plot, premise, or farm.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Latvia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Macedonia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: While State owns the soil, communities & their members own rights to the land in accordance with custom or by occupation in good faith and may register these rights as DUATS with equivalent force to DUATS not acquired on basis of custom or occupation.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: While all land is vested in State Governors or Local Government Authorities (LGA) as trustees, customary right holders are assumed to be lawful possessors without certificates.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous communities in Nicaragua are granted ownership rights that are recognized and protected by the 1987 Constitution. The Statute Autonomy of the Atlantic Coast (187) and the Communal Land Law(2003) provide indigenous peoples with the right to own and use communal lands based on their traditional and customary patterns of land and resource use and occupancy.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Supreme Court in 2001 found that the Sami population in Svartskogen (in northern Norway) were the rightful owners of their lands. The Finmark Act 2005 recognizes Sami territorial rights to use lands and water held in Finnmark County, but these rights do not extend beyond the county of Finnmark.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Land is divided into three tenure types: state land, private land, and Guthi (religious) land. Communities are granted user rights to forests, but the state retains broad power to extinguish forest areas collectively held and used by communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Title to customary land is recognized by statute (the TTWA 1993) and New Zealand also recognizes the doctrine of aboriginal title (same as Australia, Canada, USA) under common law. The TTWA 1993 recognizes Maori customary land and Maori freehold land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution recognizes customary law and the Federally Administered Tribal Areas, which follow customary tenure systems (Pashtunwali) and provide for collective tenure and community based land governance by villages, clans and shura.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution of Panama recognizes the ownership rights of indigenous communities to their land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The law provides clear ownership rights to communities that hold customary land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Poland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Portugal that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Article 64 of the Constitution recognizes the communal ownership rights of the indigenous communities of Paraguay. Indigenous peoples access to land is regulated in the Indigenous Communities Statute (1981). However, the constitutional rights granted to indigenous communities have not been supported by legislation or regulations, resulting in potential conflict between communities and the state.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Romania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Although most recognized parcels have roots in customary ownership the customary regime is extinguished at registration. Many rights curtailed including to common lands.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The law is explicit that Malays are the indigenous people of Singapore. Beyond that, however, little legal protection is specifically given to land-rights. In addition, the indigenous fishing communities of the Seletar (also know an the Orang Asli Laut) are not given formal legal recognition or protection.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Since 1927 customary rights accorded full legal support as owned lands, vested in Tribal Authorities (TA) as trustees for communities. TA govern lands by customary law, which is given full constitutional support as the applicable law in 85% of country.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Slovakia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Sami have a recognized right to co-manage land within the Laponia Tjuottjudus (Laponia World Heritage Site). However, Sami land rights are not statutorily recognized outside of the Laponia World Heritage Site.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not recognize land rights held by indigenous or local communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Tajikistan that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The law establishes that 'community property is the land that it is used in common by a community, according to their customary practices'. There is no restriction to the type of property that can be owned by a community.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Article 4 of the Law on Pastures, 1998 provides that villages have right to use rangelands, pastures and winter pastrues.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Ukraine that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution recognizes collective ownership of lands of native peoples, which are inalienable, nontransferable, indefeasible, and imprescriptible

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Communities may only be allocated land use rights through certificates. The State retains broad authority to recover land use rights granted to communities.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Yemen's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights. Yemen's State Land Authority estimates that 90 percent of all land in Yemen is state owned.

indicatorLabel: I - Legal Status - Indigenous People
note: Customary land is vested in the State or in the Ingonyama Trust in KawZulu Natal. Nevertheless rights protected as if property.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: MIXED. Strong in ways e.g. titled community lands protected against issue of concessions. Weak in most other ways e.g. require title for protection, title excludes natural resources/commons other than limited pasture and livestock routes.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Main intention of the law is to protect customary rights explicitly including collective rights, and provide for their certification. Unclear that if unregistered due same level of compensation at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: IP and LC's lands receive the same level of protection as forms of private agricultural property (recognition, protection and guarantee over rights). Customary land rights are recognized but formalization is promoted and needed.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Quilombo communities receive the same level of protection as other types of private property, including compensation for expropriation. In instances of overlapping rights with regard to third parties laws favor the rights of the Quilombo communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: MIXED: e.g. strong in that law protects unregistered customary rights, pays prior compensation at compulsory acquisition;  weak in that focused on  individual rights and only to houses & farms, no protection of family & community rights.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Land rights for communities have the same level of property rights as private land ownership, including compensation for expropriation. But registration is required to receive protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: No automatic protection for pastoral, agro-pastoral or village rights and no provision for collective tenure other than via legal entities, but assistance given for formation.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Some protection in that allocated or confirmed rights to house & farm plots equally subject to compensation at compulsory acquisition and by agreement. But customary rights repealed & no provision common properties.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Community land is a subject-matter which is not recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The law explicitly states that the exploitation right granted to rural communities is not a proprietary right, so the level of protection is not the same as that given to private property owners.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The FRA 2006 gives communities land rights which are equivalent level of protection given to private property owners (compensation from expropriation, etc.), but communities have to register their forest rights before receiving this protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Federal legislation only provides for government and private ownership rights. The laws are silent on community land rights.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Equitable protection at compulsory acquisition for customary/community rights but details not yet enacted (Community Land Bill). Protection against trustees disposing of lands prior to registration but insecurity  threatens due to slow process.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Existing rights protected in that formalization is not compulsory, same compensation as lessees at compulsory acquisition, although scope for lawful takings is high. Authority vested in community councils.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The Constitution and the Agrarian establish that ejido land must be protected by law, but ejidos must be registered to receive protection and cannot sell or lease their land as freely as private property owners (need to go through Ejido assemblies).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Since herding communities are only granted possession contracts, the law does not give communities the same level of protection as it gives rights to private property owners.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Although provided for & administered under customary law, community/customary lands statutorily curtailed by state ownership with full disposal powers and compulsory privatization extinguishing customary rights & norms. Compensation only communities & traditional authorities cannot reject state's decision to privatize and/or take these for loosely defined purposes with loss of customary jurisdiction & norms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Limited; control vested in unelected chiefs; compensation at compulsory acquisition only for improvements to land; compulsory registration of rights for residences & farms, leaving commons firmly in hands of chiefs.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The integrity of their customary land rights is secured and recognized over third party land possession. Community land rights have a constitutional level of recognition and receive protection the same as other type of property, but must register to receive protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Some protection for use rights. Protection for registered usufructs and 'lawful users even if not registered' and due compensation at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Land classified as public, community or private. Public land owned collectively by citizens, a residual category (neither community nor private land). Customary law determines community rights. Legal title not required to prove ownership.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Mixed: protected through definition of rights in customary domain (Swazi National Land) as property due equitable compensation. Less protection with no provision for certificates & subject to whom if King-led traditional authority.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: None. Communities can lose untitled individual, private and collective lands at will without the State having to prove a public purpose as registered in the name of the State.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Since communities can only manage and use state-owned land under a "Community Land Use Permit", community land rights do not receive the same level of protection as rights acquired under freehold tenure.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: a) Granted & customary rights have same status; b) compensation equitable for granted & customary rights; c) collective ownership& lands accepted, etc. (see additional info).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: a) As customary tenure does not require registered entitlements, law upholds customary rights without formalization. (b) Family & collective property included. (c)  Constitutionally, equitable compensation at compulsory acquisition obligatory.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: High, given that rights may exist without registration, cannot be alienated into leasehold without approval of chief, and no legal indication that lands under unregistered customary rights will not be considered equally to lands under leasehold tenure.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Mixed: significant given setting aside of lands as Communal Lands, introduction of gazetted village boundaries, devolved roles to village heads, but curtailed by powers of  President/Council to declare lands for other uses, transfer to State Land, evicting or relocating occupants & to vary rights & permits.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The Aland Parliament retains power to decide who can domicile within the islands. The Aland Parliament can acquire real property within Aland under the Act on the 1975 Act on the Acquisition of Real Property in Aland.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The agricultural authorities are legally empowered to determine which properties are agricultural community property (Sec. 17, federal skeletal law). The government can expropriate commonly held agricultural land for a public purpose.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The national level law does not explicitly grant rural communities rights to community forests in Bulgaria. Control and management of community forests is vested in municipalities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of rural communities in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: State-level (cantonal) laws recognize community rights to "Group inherited" forests and common pastures (e.g. Canton Graub√ºnden). However, since LandMark's assessment is limited to national level laws, state-level laws are not assessed. There are no explicit provisions recognizing and protecting community land rights in federal laws.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The state retains authority to expropriate agricultural community property upon paying just compensation (Art. 31, 40, Law No. 5 on Agricultural Communities).
