The Agrarian Reform Corporation retains overarching authority over agricultural land owned by communities. Voluntary transfers of rights held by agricultural communities may be authorized by the Head of the Land Office (Art. 39, Law on Agricultural Communities).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Collectively-owned properties are protected by law, but the right only takes effect upon registration. The State retains broad power to expropriate or requisition collectively-owned property.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Positive given focus of 1998 land law upon securing customary rights including collectively but outweighed by unjust & unworkable conditions for recognition and high vulnerability to loss of rights if remain unregistered by 2019.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Mixed: positively, groups may be registered as owners. Negatively, the law is contradictory on whether only developed lands may be subject of title, and ambivalent on status of rights prior to registration.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The Ministry of Agriculture retains authority to expropriate and transfer rural cooperative land for other uses.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Community forests are granted the same level of legal protection as private ownership rights.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Article 57(4) of the Constitution provides that indigenous communes and communities can "keep ownership, without subject to a statute of limitations, of their community lands, which shall be unalienable, immune from seizure and indivisible." However, registration is required to receive protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: According to a secondary source (see comments box), some privately owned forests in Spain are held and managed collectively in practice. However, the national law on Forests (Law No. 43/2004) does not explicitly grant communities rights to forest lands.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Assured provision and protection of rural holdings undermined by potential for redistributions, strength of government right to expropriate for private investor use and urban expansion, weak provision for communal holdings, and variable compensation at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The Aland Parliament retains power to decide who can domicile within the islands. The Aland Parliament can acquire real property within Aland under the Act on the 1975 Act on the Acquisition of Real Property in Aland.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Protection weak due to: (a) legal failure to recognize customary rights as property interests; (b) limitation to occupation & use rights in settlements; (c) limitation of compensation to such rights; (d) classification of major community resource - forests - as State property; (e) minimal protection from allocations of concessions & leases beyond settlements.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Constitution entrenches equitable status for customary and statutory rights, including at compulsory acquisition for public purposes. However land taking by chiefs is insufficiently regulated under customary & statutory law.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Mixed: positive with recognition of customary law and land rights and by restrictions on alienation to non-indigenes, but negative by right of State to redesignate as state lands to issue leases; limited inclusion of off-farm lands as customary estate; & lesser compensation at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The Forestry Commission has broad authority to grant or deny the community group a CFMA. The government may suspend, amend, or revoke State Forest Authorizations (including CFMAs (Sec. 18, Forest Act of 2009)).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulator framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Hungary.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The Agrarian Reform Authority has broad discretion to determine the limits of the agricultural land can requisition any excess of such limits.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Communal land is not recognized in any of the Israeli laws assessed.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: National-level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous or local communities. However, collective property rights of rural communities in Northern Italy are recognized by state-level laws in Trentino.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Jamaica's statutory and regulatory frameworks do not recognize the land rights of the Maroons and has not accepted or rejected the treaty between the Maroons and Great Britain

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Pasture User Unions are granted the right to represent the interests of pasture users; however, the state retains underlying ownership and Article 4 of the Law on Pastures grants local self-government broad power to control and manage pastures.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Local communities are granted tradional user rights under Community Forest Agreements. However, these rights are not as protected as other tenure regimes e.g. freehold tenure.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The Land Law 2003 provides several ways in which collectively held land use rights can be expropriated, re-allocated, or otherwise extinguished by the government. Land use rights are not as protected as ownership rights.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: While demonstrably insecure in practice, the law partially protects rights by disallowing public lands to be titled without consent of Tribal Authority and by recognition of most forestlands as community property Unclarity of status of customarylands at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Real rights to land cannot be established unless registered; registration cannot be based on customary rights. Compensation limited to developments on the land. Civil Code provides for family tenure for limited duration (15 yrs.).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Latvia.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights in Macedonia.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Good protection as communities are recognised owners of rights of use & benefit with/without formalization, includes off-farm resources, and due equitable compensation for improvements to land. But also vulnerable due to easy reclassification of lands for investors, conservation, etc.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Mixed: recognition of customary rights provided legally but with conflicts of interest evidence in decision-making by LGA, making rights vulnerable to corruption. Governor may issue statutory rights over customary lands.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The Constitution grants community ownership rights the same level of protection as those granted under other tenure regimes (private property). However, the government retains authority to limit property rights to expropriated property (Art. 44). The government can also grant concessions to communal lands so long as it consults the indigenous community (Article 16, Law 445). Communities must register to receive protection (Art. 39-51, Law 445).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Section 1-2 of Act relating to bygd commons provides circumstances in which bygd commons can be sold, leased, and expropriated.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Rights granted to Community Forest User Groups are not given the same level of protection as private ownership rights. Community Forests are easily extinguishable.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Pakistan's statutory legal system grants the government broad power to expropriate land within the territory of Pakistan. Statutory laws are silent on the extent to which community lands held under customary tenure are protected.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Customary land is granted the same level of legal protection as state land. Customary land rights are legally recognized without registration, but the state has broad authority to expropriate and issue leases to customary lands.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The national level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of local communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Article 4 of the Law on Baldios provides that acts of legal ownership or seizure are void. However, the government can still expropriate wasteland for public purposes (Art. 29, Law on Baldios; Law No. 168/99 on Land Expropriation).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Article 95 of the 2008 Forest Code establishes that community forests are guaranteed, indivisible and inalienable.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Positive for registered lands, negative for former communal rights and lands affecting community marshlands and forests.  Fair law for compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Inconsistent legal picture: positive in that 'non-natives' may only acquire lands with consent of Traditional Authority & all interests at compulsory acquisition for public purpose are constitutionally eligible for compensation. Not echoed in all statutes.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Community forests may be expropriated and the legal restrictions on buying or selling forest land do not apply to community forests.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory legal frameworks do not recognize land rights held by indigenous or local communities. The land reform imposes limitations on the ownership of land so that any excess land owned by an individual is expropriated by the state.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Community use rights to pastures are not as protected as full ownership rights. The government retains broad authority may terminate the leases granted to Pasture User Unions early.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The law does not  regulate how community property is acquired and which protection is given to this type of land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: While villages are granted the right to use pastures and rangelands, the state retains underlying authority over the pastures and has discretion dispose of rights to these areas.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The state retains broad authority transfer, purchase, withdraw, expropriate, confiscate, and terminate land  and forest rights held by communities (Articles 9-12, 143-149, Land Code).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Communities must be allocated land use rights by the state and granted land use certificates, but the State retains broad authority to take back land allocated to communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Yemen's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights. A portion of state land is designated for "public use" which includes lands for grazing and collection of firewood, and provides for limited collective use rights (usufruct), but not outright ownership.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Community Lands
note: Difficult to take customary or community lands except for public purpose in which cases same conditions as for registered property apply.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: MIXED. Strong in ways e.g. titled community lands protected against issue of concessions. Weak in most other ways e.g. require title for protection, title excludes natural resources/commons other than limited pasture and livestock routes.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: While the Constitution calls for Congress to respect indigenous/ community land rights, federal legislation, which implements this legislative directive, has not been enacted.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Native title is not given equal statutory protection as freehold tenure, and native titles must be registered to take effect and can be extinguished by the gov't under a wide range of circumstances.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Main intention of the law is to protect customary rights explicitly including collective rights, and provide for their certification. Unclear that if unregistered due same level of compensation at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: IP and LC's lands receive the same level of protection as forms of private agricultural property (recognition, protection and guarantee over rights). Customary land rights are recognized but formalization is promoted and needed.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The land rights granted to indigenous people is that of permanent possession with the exclusive right to natural resources of the soil, rivers, and lakes. This is the same level of protection of land rights as other nationals.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: MIXED: e.g. strong in that law protects unregistered customary rights, pays prior compensation at compulsory acquisition;  weak in that focused on  individual rights and only to houses & farms, no protection of family & community rights.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous communities (ICs) must register to obtain land rights (or be granted treaty rights). While some treaties grant fee simple ownership to aboriginals, the Supreme Court held that (non-treaty based) aboriginal title is not equated with a fee simple ownership interest.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Land rights for communities have the same level of property rights as private land ownership, including compensation for expropriation. But registration is required to receive protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: No automatic protection for pastoral, agro-pastoral or village rights and no provision for collective tenure other than via legal entities, but assistance given for formation.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Some protection in that allocated or confirmed rights to house & farm plots equally subject to compensation at compulsory acquisition and by agreement. But customary rights repealed & no provision common properties.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous land rights are not explicitly recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The Constitutional Court held that customary forests must be included as a category of "titled forests" so same level of protection as other titled forests. But State decides on categories.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The FRA 2006 gives communities land rights which are equivalent level of protection given to private property owners (compensation from expropriation, etc.), but communities have to register their forest rights before receiving this protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Equitable protection at compulsory acquisition for customary/community rights but details not yet enacted (Community Land Bill). Protection against trustees disposing of lands prior to registration but insecurity  threatens due to slow process.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The law provides collective ownership and includes all of the rights and protections of owners as are enjoyed by private owners. However, communities with collective ownership rights do not have the right to dispose of any collective ownership that is State public property to any person or group.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Existing rights protected in that formalization is not compulsory, same compensation as lessees at compulsory acquisition, although scope for lawful takings is high. Authority vested in community councils.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution and the Agrarian Law establish that comunidad land must be protected by law. However, comunidades must register to receive protection and the gov't retains broad power to expropriate their land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Since herding communities are only granted possession contracts, the law does not give communities the same level of protection as it gives rights to private property owners.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Although provided for & administered under customary law, community/customary lands statutorily curtailed by state ownership with full disposal powers and compulsory privatization extinguishing customary rights & norms. Compensation only communities & traditional authorities cannot reject state's decision to privatize and/or take these for loosely defined purposes with loss of customary jurisdiction & norms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The Federal Court held indigenous communities (ICs) have proprietary interest in their land, but ICs do not have statutory protection at the federal level.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Limited; control vested in unelected chiefs; compensation at compulsory acquisition only for improvements to land; compulsory registration of rights for residences & farms, leaving commons firmly in hands of chiefs.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The integrity of their customary land rights is secured and recognized over third party land possession. Community land rights have a constitutional level of recognition and receive protection the same as other type of property, but must register to receive protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Ancestral domains regarded as private but community property, owned under native title (title/pre-conquest rights), but formal registration encouraged.  Relocation and displacement for any reason is subject to consent and compensation. However, scope of ancestral domains may be limited by the provision in law recognizing existing or vested rights within ancestral domains (Sec. 56).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Federal Laws No. 49-FS, No. 104-FS, and No. 82-FS provide some legal protection to indigenous community land, but the gov't maintains broad authority over these lands.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Some protection for use rights. Protection for registered usufructs and 'lawful users even if not registered' and due compensation at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Land classified as public, community or private. Public land owned collectively by citizens, a residual category (neither community nor private land). Customary law determines community rights. Legal title not required to prove ownership.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Mixed: protected through definition of rights in customary domain (Swazi National Land) as property due equitable compensation. Less protection with no provision for certificates & subject to whom if King-led traditional authority.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: None. Communities can lose untitled individual, private and collective lands at will without the State having to prove a public purpose as registered in the name of the State.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Since communities can only manage and use state-owned land under a "Community Land Use Permit", community land rights do not receive the same level of protection as rights acquired under freehold tenure.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: a) Granted & customary rights have same status; b) compensation equitable for granted & customary rights; c) collective ownership& lands accepted, etc. (see additional info).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: a) As customary tenure does not require  registered entitlements, law upholds customary rights without formalization. (b) Family & collective property included. (c)  Constitutionally, equitable compensation at compulsory acquisition obligatory.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The degree of protection varies depending on source (statute, treaty, etc.) which defines those rights. In general, Native Americans are often granted use/ occupancy rights to reserve land held by the government. But occupancy is considered "as sacred as the fee" by SC.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: High, given that rights may exist without registration, cannot be alienated into leasehold without approval of chief, and no legal indication that lands under unregistered customary rights will not be considered equally to lands under leasehold tenure.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Mixed: significant given setting aside of lands as Communal Lands, introduction of gazetted village boundaries, devolved roles to village heads, but curtailed by powers of  President/Council to declare lands for other uses, transfer to State Land, evicting or relocating occupants & to vary rights & permits.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Austria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Bulgaria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher found no evidence of indigenous community land in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Switzerland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Article 13 of Law No. 19253 provides that indigenous lands may not be sold, seized, taxed or acquired by prescription, except between communities or indigenous people of the same ethnic group. All land owned by communities may not be leased, given on loan, or assigned to third parties in use, enjoyment or administration. Article 3 and Article 12 of Law No. 12253 indicates that indigenous land must be registered to receive the legal protection under Law No. 19253.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Collectively-owned properties are protected by law, but the right only takes effect upon registration. The State retains broad power to expropriate or requisition collectively-owned property.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Positive given focus of 1998 land law upon securing customary rights including collectively but outweighed by unjust & unworkable conditions for recognition and high vulnerability to loss of rights if remain unregistered by 2019.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The law protects IP land rights even without registration. Off-farm lands are protected if these are part of the collective or individual property of IP. They are eligible for compensation as if private property at compulsory acquisition but no legal description of public purposes.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Art. 3 of Law No. 6172 provides that Indigenous reserves are inalienable and not transferable and exclusive to the indigenous communities that inhabit them. Nonindigenous people may not rent, lease, purchase or otherwise acquire land or farms falling within these reserves. But indigenous land may be expropriated (Art. 5, Law No.6172) and IPs must register to received legal protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The law does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous peoples in Cuba.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Germany that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Article 57(4) of the Constitution provides that indigenous communes and communities can "keep ownership, without subject to a statute of limitations, of their community lands, which shall be unalienable, immune from seizure and indivisible." However, registration is required to receive protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Spain that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Assured provision and protection of rural holdings undermined by potential for redistributions, strength of government right to expropriate for private investor use and urban expansion, weak provision for communal holdings, and variable compensation at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Finland's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize and protect the land rights of Sami populations in Finland.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Protection weak due to: (a) legal failure to recognize customary rights as property interests; (b) limitation to occupation & use rights in settlements; (c) limitation of compensation to such rights; (d) classification of major community resource - forests - as State property; (e) minimal protection from allocations of concessions & leases beyond settlements.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Constitution entrenches equitable status for customary and statutory rights, including at compulsory acquisition for public purposes. However land taking by chiefs is insufficiently regulated under customary & statutory law.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Mixed: positive with recognition of customary law and land rights and by restrictions on alienation to non-indigenes, but negative by right of State to redesignate as state lands to issue leases; limited inclusion of off-farm lands as customary estate; & lesser compensation at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The President retains broad authority to revoke Amerindian land rights granted under the State Lands Act. Amerindian land can be leased and expropriated for large-scale mining projects and other public purposes (Sec. 50, Amerindian Act; Sec. 142, Constitution). Titles to Amerindian land can be revoked in the public interest, or if Amerindians transfer rights to their lands in contravention of laws.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Article 95 of the 2004 Property Law provides that if the State intends the exploitation of natural resources in indigenous territories, it must inform and consult the affected indigenous populations before authorizing any inspection or exploitation. When the government authorizes exploitation, indigenous people must receive fair compensation for any damages that result from these activities. However, in order to receive protection under the 2004 Property Law, indigenous communities must register following the procedures established in the Property Law.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Hungary that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory frameworks do not explicitly grant indigenous communities (Assyrians) land rights in Iraq

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Communal land is not recognized in any of the Israeli laws assessed.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Italy that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The Land Law 2003 provides several ways in which collectively held land use rights can be expropriated, re-allocated, or otherwise extinguished by the government. Land use rights are not as protected as ownership rights.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: While demonstrably insecure in practice, the law partially protects rights by disallowing public lands to be titled without consent of Tribal Authority and by recognition of most forestlands as community property Unclarity of status of customarylands at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Real rights to land cannot be established unless registered; registration cannot be based on customary rights. Compensation limited to developments on the land. Civil Code provides for family tenure for limited duration (15 yrs.).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Latvia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Macedonia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Good protection as communities are recognised owners of rights of use & benefit with/without formalization, includes off-farm resources, and due equitable compensation for improvements to land. But also vulnerable due to easy reclassification of lands for investors, conservation, etc.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Mixed: recognition of customary rights provided legally but with conflicts of interest evidence in decision-making by LGA, making rights vulnerable to corruption. Governor may issue statutory rights over customary lands.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution grants community ownership rights the same level of protection as those granted under other tenure regimes (private property). However, the government retains authority to limit property rights to expropriated property (Art. 44). The government can also grant concessions to communal lands so long as it consults the indigenous community (Article 16, Law 445). Communities must register to receive protection (Art. 39-51, Law 445).

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The laws states that it does not interfere with the individual rights acquired by Sami and other people through prescription or immemorial usage. However, the government bodies: Sami Parliament, the Finnmark estate, the Finnmark Commission, and the Land Consolidation Court retain broad authority over lands held by the Sami population.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Rights granted to Community Forest User Groups are not given the same level of protection as private ownership rights. Community Forests are easily extinguishable.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Maori customary landholders can obtain ownership rights to Maori freehold land by applying to the Maori Land Court for "Maori freehold status", but the Court has discretion to approve or deny.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Pakistan's statutory legal system grants the government broad power to expropriate land within the territory of Pakistan. Statutory laws are silent on the extent to which community lands held under customary tenure are protected.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: According to Art. 9 of Act No. 72 of 2008, the land title awarded to indigenous communities is collective, indefinite, non-transferable, irrevocable and inalienable. Registration following the procedures established in Act No. 72 of 2008 is required to receive formal legal protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Customary land is granted the same level of legal protection as state land. Customary land rights are legally recognized without registration, but the state has broad authority to expropriate and issue leases to customary lands.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Poland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Portugal that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Article 64 of the Constitution provides that lands owned by indigenous peoples are non-seizable, indivisible, non-transferrable, imprescriptible, not susceptible to guarantee contractual obligations nor to be leased. Furthermore the removal or transfer of the indigenous peoples from their habitat without their express consent is prohibited. However, indigenous communities must register under the 1981 Indigenous Communities Statute to receive legal protection. Legislation implementing indigenous constitutional rights has not yet been passed.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Romania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Positive for registered lands, negative for former communal rights and lands affecting community marshlands and forests.  Fair law for compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The law is explicit that Malays are the indigenous people of Singapore. Beyond that, however, little legal protection is specifically given to land rights. In addition, the indigenous fishing communities of the Seletar (also know an the Orang Asli Laut) are not given formal legal recognition or protection.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Inconsistent legal picture: positive in that 'non-natives' may only acquire lands with consent of Traditional Authority & all interests at compulsory acquisition for public purpose are constitutionally eligible for compensation. Not echoed in all statutes.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Slovakia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Sami land rights are only protected for the purpose of co-managing land held within the Laponia World Heritage Site, and thus these rights are not as protected as fee simple ownership rights or other tenure rights.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not recognize land rights held by indigenous or local communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Tajikistan that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The law does not  regulate how community property is acquired and which protection is given to this type of land.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: While villages are granted the right to use pastures and rangelands, the state retains underlying authority over the pastures and has discretion dispose of rights to these areas.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Ukraine that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Community land receives the same protections as other types of property. It is unclear whether the land must be registered to receive these protections.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Communities must be allocated land use rights by the state and granted land use certificates, but the State retains broad authority to take back land allocated to communities.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Yemen's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights. A portion of state land is designated for "public use" which includes lands for grazing and collection of firewood, and provides for limited collective use rights (usufruct), but not outright ownership.

indicatorLabel: II - Land Rights and Common Property - Indigenous People
note: Difficult to take customary or community lands except for public purpose in which cases same conditions as for registered property apply.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Customary title encouraged & fully provided for, accessible, free of charges, requires consultation with traditional leaders and families, maps & document issued.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Provides for decentralised & cheap issue of Certificate of Possession of Rural Land (RWA) to individuals & groups on basis of localized adjudication. Also provides for Local Land Charters through which customary rules defined & upheld by communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Formalization is promoted and applied ex-officio by the state the same as by request of the communities. Procedure free of cost to grant lands to PIOC, ICO, and PC as community lands.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note:
It is not mandatory but is promoted to reinforce Quilombo communities' land rights. Demarcation following self-assessment of Quilombo communities.
The procedure is done at no cost to the community and provides  legal title over the land

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Easy & free procedure for individuals to secure Certificate of Customary Rights. Only sketch map required. Common law leases to customary land require formal survey & registration in Deeds Registry.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Indigenous territory is recognized without the distinction of the legal title. The law incentivizes formalization of land as a way to secure formal entitlement in lands from where communities were previously displaced by the armed conflict.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Provides amply for cooperative development by communities for arable farming including expansion into pastoral lands/steppes by agropastoralists. State, district and communes all bound to assist citizens to expand arable farming & state & local governments legally bound to assist. Uncertain provision for pastoralist use.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Provided for only for small sector of lands in form of individual  house & arable farm. Security dependent on issue title of allotted parcels. Remote administration.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Community land is a subject-matter which is not recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The Regulation does not establish clear, accessible, affordable procedures for formally establishing rural community institutions.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Registration is free. The FRA 2006 provides that the Gram Sabha (traditional village institutions) must receive and decide on claims to community forests, and prepare a map delineating the area of each claim.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Federal legislation only provides for government and private ownership rights. The laws are silent on community land rights.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Formalization obligatory (community land titles) & time-bound (2022) but slow progress and present draft law stipulates onerous, costly, state-dependent procedure.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Certification for residential & agricultural uses accessible because issued by Community Councils. Costs unknown. Certificates & leases not compulsory.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Registration is free. The law establishes clear, accessible procedures for demarcating, mapping, and registering ejido/comunidad land. Federal agencies must assist ejidos/comunidades in securing land.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Articles 31- 34 provides clear procedures for requesting a possession contract. The contract must include a map, description of the land, etc. But no provisions on affordability/accessibility.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: While occupancy & use protected by customary law as administered by chiefs, no provision for registration of these use rights, and ownership only registrable on public land (leasehold) or private land  by extinction of customary right.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Law provides compulsory registration of customary rights to houses & farms, provision for collective entitlement limited to legal entities or to families & groups for residential & farming.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Land titling administrative procedure is free of cost for communities. Formal entitlement of community lands is of national interest (Law 24657, Art. 2) and has preference over previous legal title granted to third parties (Law 22175, Art. 12).

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Registration can be made compulsory by Presidential Order. No provision for formalization of community ownership but provision exists for family tenure limited to 15 years. Provision for individual, family & community usufruct to be registered.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Intended that all land rights will be registered, intended through systematic registration, but not compulsory until that event. Provision for local level land councils (payam, county) and duty of county governments to assist as needed.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: No provision for certification of customary rights (individual, household, collective rights). No statute governing customary rights and customary law unwritten.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Ownership & protection of rights is only available through securing non-customary land title, available only to individuals and legal entities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Regulation allows for communities to formally register their customary land use permits, but it is unclear whether a detailed and georeferenced map of communal property is provided. Also unclear if procedures are affordable or accessible.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Formalization (Certificates of Customary Occupancy) is voluntary. Adjudication & registration localized with Village Land Registers, allocations subject to approval of Village Assembly.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Families, communities & individuals may acquire certificates of customary ownership &/or create Communal Land Associations. Process simple, cheap, but handicapped by weak supporting admin. & perceived inequity for customary interests.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Only via conversion of customary right into leasehold tenure. Procedure is free, accessible, voluntary and subject to chief's consent. No provision for collective leasehold except as legal entity.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Provision of occupation permits to households for agriculture & residence, no provision for collective rights to grazing, forests, etc. below level of Rural Council and President.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The law sets out clear requirements for domiciling on the Aland Islands, but it is unclear based on the law whether procedures are affordable and accessible.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The federal legislation does not establish registration processes for demarcating or formalizing community pasture rights. Presumably, these processes are laid out in provincial legislation (However, LandMark's assessment is limited to national level legislation). In the federal skeletal law, there are no clear provisions ensuring agrarian communities are able to easily access and afford registration processes.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The national level law does not explicitly grant rural communities rights to community forests in Bulgaria. Control and management of community forests is vested in municipalities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of rural communities in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: State-level (cantonal) laws recognize community rights to "Group inherited" forests and common pastures (e.g. Canton Graub√ºnden). However, since LandMark's assessment is limited to national level laws, state-level laws are not assessed. There are no explicit provisions recognizing and protecting community land rights in federal laws.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Articles 4-6 of Law No. 5 on Agricultural Communities establishes the procedures by which community property may be registered. However, there are no clear provisions ensuring that the registration process will be affordable or accessible.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: While the law is silent on whether registration must be affordable, there are clearly defined procedures and collectives can obtain government assistance in registering their land.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Law stipulates compulsory certification of customary rights as basis for extinction and replacement with statutory rights for individuals and corporate entities only. Also too costly.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Each district must establish a committee to identify, adjudicate including conflict resolution, record and issue provisional licences for customary rights. Concessions may also be issued to communities. Developed (farmed) lands may be registered.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Rural communities can obtain rights to use land by obtaining the approval of the Ministry of Agriculture. However, there are no clear provisions for demarcating or ensuring farmers are able to afford and access registration procedures.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Section 38 of the Federal Forest Act establishes the requirements for creating a forestry association, and more specific procedures are presumably laid out in state laws and regulations. In the Federal Forest Act, there are no clear provision ensuring that communities have financial and other assistance enabling them to easily register as Forest Associations.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Article 60 of the Constitution provides "Ancestral, indigenous, Afro-Ecuadorian and coastal back-country (montubios) peoples can establish territorial districts for the preservation of their culture. The law shall regulate their establishment. Communities (comunas) that have collective land ownership are recognized as an ancestral form of territorial organization." Community land was registered under the Law of the Communas 1936, but is unclear whether the registration procedures are accessible and not cumbersome.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: According to a secondary source (see comments box), some privately owned forests in Spain are held and managed collectively in practice. However, the national law on Forests (Law No. 43/2004) does not explicitly grant communities rights to forest lands.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Legal provision for low-cost, community based adjudication and issue of certificates of rural rights to individuals, spouses, communities but excludes  substantial off-farm lands. Lack of cadastral registration law weakens rights given high level of competing allocation to investors.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The law sets out clear requirements for domiciling on the Aland Islands, but it is unclear based on the law whether procedures are affordable and accessible.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Legal encouragement to get titles for up to 10 ha of 'evidentially occupied' land in recognized settlements, a free process, devolved to district governments, but low uptake.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Law provides for formalization of customary rights on State and Customary Lands but criteria are impractical, inaccessible & costly. Rights recorded by Customary Secretariats lack equivalency with title registration.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: While customary rights accorded legal support without registration, there is no legal process for issue of registrable customary titles. Consent of Traditional Authorities ('District Authorities') for statutory leases required which they also then regulate but with no legal guidance. May issue Certificates of Occupancy.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The Forest Act does not contain clear procedures for establishing CFMAs. There is no indication that CFMAs are accessible or affordable.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulator framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Hungary.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The law establishes a process for registering collective farmland, but it is unclear whether the process is accessible and affordable for collectives.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Communal land is not recognized in any of the Israeli laws assessed.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: National-level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous or local communities. However, collective property rights of rural communities in Northern Italy are recognized by state-level laws in Trentino.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Jamaica's statutory and regulatory frameworks do not recognize the land rights of the Maroons and has not accepted or rejected the treaty between the Maroons and Great Britain

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The registration process for creating Pasture User Unions is compulsory, and the law does not establish assistance mechanisms to ensure registration is affordable and accessible.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Local communities can obtain rights under a Community Forest Agreement for the purpose of implementing sustainable use and development of forest resources. However, there is no clear process for formalizing, demarcating, and otherwise registering community forests. There are also no provisions in the Forestry Law ensuring that communities are able to easily access and afford registration procedures.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Individuals and organizations may request and be issued land use certificates, land survey certificates or land title for customary land. However the procedures and legal provisions ensuring affordability and accessibility.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Communities may formalise tribal reserves/ communal holdings as encumbrances on Public Land or transform to statutory rights through purchase of public lands. Policy commitment to make community/customary rights directly registrable is not yet in law.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Registration is a prerequisite for recognizing rights but tribes and sub-tribal units are not registrable holders (1965 Law providing for this annulled). Claims based on customary/tribal ownership not permitted.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Latvia.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights in Macedonia.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Formalization of rights is voluntary, straightforward, with improving stipulations for representation of  community members. Communities, groups, individuals may apply for titles as registered rights for other than protected and partially protected areas.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Voluntary registration on basis of sketch & details to Local Government Administration (LGA) subject to unelected Land Committee decision. Expensive procedure.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Law 445 establishes clear procedures for formalizing indigenous and community land, but is unclear whether these procedures are affordable and accessible for communities. Communities can either demarcate land as a community or as a territory.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The law provides that land held within bygd commons must be registered, but it is unclear whether this process is accessible and inexpensive for commoners.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: There are clear procedures for establishing Community Forest User Groups, and the Work Plan must include maps and details of the forests granted to communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Pakistan's statutory legal system provide a formal process of registering or titling community property held under customary tenure.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Registration and delimitation of community lands in order to establish ownership is voluntary. The procedures are clear, accessible, and free.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The national level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of local communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Article 14 of the Law on Baldios establishes that compartes assemblies are empowered to decide on matters relating to registration. However, there is no clear registration process established in the Law on Baldios (and no implementing regulations establishing demarcation or registration processes). There are no provisions ensuring registration will be affordable and accessible for local communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The Forest Code establishes a registration process for formalizing rights held by community forests. The procedures for registration are not entirely clear, and there is no indication from the law that communes are provided financial or other assistance in the registration process.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Fully provided for, cheap, easy, and facilitated with almost full application but extinguishes customary rights & governance, and excludes common properties.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to land.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: No legal provision for customary rights to be formally registered, although leases acquired by non-natives to chiefdom lands and other contracts such as to investors may be deposited in Deeds Registry as are some intra-customary transfers.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: In Slovakia, there are two legal main ways in which communities may form community forests: 1) by forming a land association with legal entity and 2) by forming land association without "corporate entity" status. However, it is unclear whether there are provisions on affordability and accessibility.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Communal land is not recognized in federal statute and there is no mechanism to legally affirm a parcel of land as such.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The procedures for establishing Pastures User Unions and obtaining a certificate are vague. There are no clear provisions ensuring registration is accessible and affordable.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The law allows land registration, but only for individuals or groups of determined individuals. Families, groups, or communities can claim land, but there is no mechanism for registration of land in the name of that family, group or community.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The Law on Pastures establishes a Commission to administer and manage pastures, and the Commission is tasked with  administering, surveying and registering pastures and rangelands. However, the law does not ensure that the registration process will be accessible and affordable for villages.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The Land Code establishes the registration of all property within Ukraine is compulsory (Section X, Transitional Provisions).  Law No. 1457-IV regarding demarcation of public and municipal land establishes vague procedures for registering communal property (Art. 7, 12). Under the Forest Code (Art. 11), communities can acquire ownership rights to communal forests through registration, but there are no explicit legal protections ensuring the registration process is affordable or accessible.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The law on land provides clear procedures for registering land use rights, and requires the government to obtain detailed information on land parcels. However, there is no legal provision addressing the issue of affordability or accessibility.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: The Law of State Lands and Real Estate Act, s. IV (43)-(45)

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Community Lands
note: Communal Property Associations and other forms of group tenure have proved cumbersome with limited uptake. Communal Land Reform Act enabling registration of rights in former homelands repealed, leaving vacuum.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Indigenous People
note: Customary title encouraged & fully provided for, accessible, free of charges, requires consultation with traditional leaders and families, maps & document issued.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Indigenous People
note: The law requires the Register of Native Title Claims to include detailed information and a map of the land covered by a claim. Federal law established the Indigenous Land Corporation, which provides financial assistance to indigenous communities to claim native lands.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Indigenous People
note: Provides for decentralised & cheap issue of Certificate of Possession of Rural Land (RWA) to individuals & groups on basis of localized adjudication. Also provides for Local Land Charters through which customary rules defined & upheld by communities.

indicatorLabel: III - Formal Documentation - Indigenous People
