note: There is no provision recognizing families, groups and communities as legal persons, and no mechanisms to form legal entities.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Community Lands
note: Villages are granted legal personality under the Law on Pastures, but not for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Community Lands
note: The 2001 Land Code and the Forest Code recognize the legal personality of communities for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Community Lands
note: Communities are granted legal personality as land users, but they are not legal persons for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Community Lands
note: Yemen's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights. (For the same reasons indicated above.)

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Community Lands
note: For purposes of protection of informal rights, communities have status as juristic persons but registration is through cumbersome Communal Property Associations.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Judicial personhood of rural communities and legal standing to represent themselves to defend rights explicitly recognized.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Article 2 of Law No. 23.302 (1985) provides that the legal personality of indigenous communities is recognized.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The Supreme Court granted indigenous populations legal personality in several constitutional court cases, but must first register to obtain legal personality for the purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Collective rights may be directly  held and certificated as owned by families, groups or communities with no requirement to register legal entity. Note that most rural landholding is family-based.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Although IP, ICO and PC have Constitutional recognition, in order to have a legal title of their lands they need to establish a legal entity (register as a PIOC or ICO) in order to receive such a title.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous people (IP) are recognized as a legal entity for the purpose of ownership. They have standing under the law to sue in order to defend their rights and interests.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Neither families, communities, nor even the tribe have legal personality, hence vesting of ownership  in Boards (corporate entities). To secure customary use right or common law lease, family or group must form legal entity (e.g. Community Trust).

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The Supreme Court granted legal standing to indigenous communities in several constitutional cases, but they are not always legal persons for the purposes of land ownership and must first register or obtain treaty rights.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution recognizes collective property rights of indigenous territories, however indigenous reservations and community councils for Afro-Colombian communities have to be legally created for communities to hold legal title over their land.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Formation of registered entities such as cooperatives is needed for families, clans and traditional groups to acquire Certificate of Possession.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Other than for created arable coops, no provision for collective title. Also, Government can redraw village boundaries, and role of village governments (Baito) is weak.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous land rights are not explicitly recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The Basic Agrarian Law recognizes adat law, or customary law, is a source of land law as long as it does not conflict with national interests or other regulations. Indigenous communities are granted legal standing to file claims in court.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The FRA 2006 and the Land Acquisition Rehabilitation and Resettlement Act 2013 both recognize Scheduled Tribe and other traditional forest dwellers as legal persons for the purposes of land ownership. However, they must register to be recognized.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: In recognising communities as landowners the Constitution gives positive support to land being vested in and held by communities. Draft legislation suggests communities will have to form legal entities to receive title.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The law establishes the "community as a legal entity" and defines this legal entity as indigenous communities that have assembled and were officially registered at the Ministry of Interior. So first indigenous community must register.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: As legal entities, Community Councils could hold property for community but no encouraging provision to do so and with legal implication that only household land is allocated, therefore commons are vulnerable.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Comunidades are granted legal personality by the Constitution and the Agrarian Law, but must first register to obtain legal personality.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The law is silent on whether communities are granted legal personality. They are only establishes as parties to a land possession contract.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: No provision for community or other customarily established groups as legal person or stipulated avenues for securing this without transformation of land rights into freehold or leasehold rights.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: While there is no federal legislation granting legal personality to indigenous communities (ICs), the High Court of Malaysia has granted legal standing to ICs in several cases involving land rights disputes.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Only legal entities may acquire leaseholds for lands that include commons. Since 2014 families & groups may apply in own name for customary certificates but only for residential & farming units.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Peasant and Native Communities have legal existence and are legal entities according to the Constitution. Nevertheless, in order to have legal standing and receive land title communities have to register.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: ICC/IP community explicitly recognized as a legal person for purposes of delineation and issuance of ancestral domain/land titles. Title is issued in the name of the community, containing a list of all members identified in the census undertaken for the purpose.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Art. 14 of the Law "On Guarantees" provides that customary law may be used in court proceedings as long as it does not contradict federal or regional legislation, which suggests legal personality.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Villages, communities, tribes, clans or other customary associations do not have legal personality.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Land may be registered individually or collectively. Community land may optionally be registered 'in name of community, clan, family, association, or traditional leader as trustee with consent of community'.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: In customary law the community is a de facto legal person in that it can hold land right in common (and does) but not registrable.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: None for communities; have to form legal entity & apply for non-customary right to have property protection.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The Regulation grants indigenous communities temporary use rights, similar to leaseholds. However, the law does not establish the indigenous communities as legal persons for the purposes of ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Any person, family unit, group of persons recognized under customary law including the whole community is a recognized land right holder and may receive a formal Certificate of Customary Right of Occupancy, without forming legal entity.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Law recognizes customary rights held by families and communities without forming legal entity & may secure Certificates of Customary Ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Native Americans are recognized as legal persons by the Supreme Court, but not necessarily for purposes of private property ownership

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Neither community nor chief on its behalf has legal personality. No provision for collective tenure without registering legal entity to hold on behalf of members.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Villages/ communities have no legal personality. Cannot hold village area in common. Rights are for residence and farms. Communal title held by President, exercised & governed by District Councils.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Austria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Bulgaria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher found no evidence of indigenous community land in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Switzerland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Article 10 of Law 19253 recognizes the legal personality of indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The law establishes legal personality for members of the collective where decisions of the collective organizations infringe on their legal rights.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: While the law enables families & communities to acquire certificates under name of appointed manager, they cannot transform these into property titles without forming registered entities or becoming tenant of national or local government.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: An IP community may be recognized as land owner as an individual or collective.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Article 5 of the Regulation No. 8487 provides that, once legally registered, the traditional community board representative legally and extra judicially represent those communities.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The law does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous peoples in Cuba.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Germany that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Communities are granted legal personality for purposes of land ownership under the Constitution of Ecuador, 2008

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Spain that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Despite constitutional pledge to enable communities to own private property in common, no development in land laws of parameters or procedures as is provided for spousal co-ownership. Formation of legal entities in which to vest community lands is not indicated.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Finland's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize and protect the land rights of Sami populations in Finland.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Provision for registration for ownership in undivided shares by joint owners exists. Legal provision for village collectivities to be registered under local government law in 1996 but no implementation decrees issued.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: In customary law (recognized) a community, group, family may be landowner but presumption of statute is that trustee (tribal authority) or head of family is registered as owner.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Family tenure dominates customarily and is upheld by customary laws. But no statutory provision for clans, families or customary groups to register rights.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Amerindian Villages and Communities are granted legal personality for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The 2004 Property Law indicates that indigenous communities have legal personality for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Hungary that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory frameworks do not explicitly grant indigenous communities (Assyrians) land rights in Iraq

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Communal land is not recognized in any of the Israeli laws assessed.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Italy that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: While villages can apply for collective title, village clusters or groups of villages (kumbahn) that self-identify as a collective group or other groups must first form an association under the Association Decree 2009 to apply for collective rights over customary land.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Recognition of communities as legal persons as per issue of Aborigines Deeds and Public Land Deeds to communities as well as to individuals. Policy 2013 confirms community as legal person but not yet in law.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Although Law No. 142/1970 recognized tribes as owners of lands and wells registered in their names, subsequent laws rendered this ineffective. Formally, tribes or clans are not registrable as owners.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Latvia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Macedonia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Communities may acquire title to their lands on basis of custom or occupancy of 10+ years. No stipulation that must form legal entities in which to vest title.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Law says that a community is a landowner, with certificate or not.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous and ethnic communities are recognized as legal persons for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The Sami population is granted legal personality, but not for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The law does not explicitly provide communities with the rights to legal personality for the purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Maori freehold landowners are given legal personality for the purposes of land ownership. The Court has recognized the Maoris as legal persons in several cases.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Pakistan's statutory legal system does not explicitly grant customary tenure holders legally personality for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous communities are granted legal personality for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Only legal entities, known as Incorporated Land Groups (ILGs), are recognized as legal persons for the purpose of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Poland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Portugal that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous communities are recognized as legal persons for the purpose of ownership once they register following the procedures established in the Indigenous Communities Statute (1981).

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Romania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Other than married spouses, only associations of persons with legal personality may register ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to land.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The law is explicit that Malays are the indigenous people of Singapore. Beyond that, however, little legal protection is specifically given to land rights. In addition, the indigenous fishing communities of the Seletar (also know an the Orang Asli Laut) are not given formal legal recognition or protection.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Lawful for families, groups and communities to hold land in common under customary law, and which enjoys full support as part of general law so must be upheld when challenged. But no provision for formal registration of ownership by groups.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Slovakia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The Sami are recognized as legal persons, but only for their co-management rights to the land held within the Laponia World Heritage Site.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not recognize land rights held by indigenous or local communities.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Tajikistan that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: There is no provision recognizing families, groups and communities as legal persons, and no mechanisms to form legal entities.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Villages are granted legal personality under the Law on Pastures, but not for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Ukraine that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: The law explicitly recognizes the legal personhood of indigenous peoples and communities.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Communities are granted legal personality as land users, but they are not legal persons for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: Yemen's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights. (For the same reasons indicated above.)

indicatorLabel: IV - Legal Person - Indigenous People
note: For purposes of protection of informal rights, communities have status as juristic persons but registration is through cumbersome Communal Property Associations.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Rural communities defined as having collective rights to administration, and to operate according to principles of self-administration & governance.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Authority over community lands devolved to communities who set up Village Land Commissions and also develop Local Land Charters specifying community agreed rules. Local commune supervision.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: PIOC, ICO, and PC have the authority to determine the distribution of their lands according to their own customary rules (so long as it is compatible with public law). They also have autonomy to govern themselves in every level of their organization.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Quilombos communities have the right to use their lands to fulfill their physical, social, economic and cultural needs.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Village headmen & committees, elected district councils, Tribal Administration only have consultation roles, no decision-making powers. Boards not fully localised & undemocratic, also must comply with state directions.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Indigenous authorities are competent to govern their territories, to apply customary administrative and judiciary rules, to freely manage their natural resources, and to govern according to their internal regulations and social organization.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Local government communes may hold lands for communities or allocate use rights. Cooperatives have authority over allocated lands.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Mixed: legal land authority vested in Land Administration Bodies at provincial level l(zoba) but 699 village clusters elect governments and have de facto authority in vacuum of application.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Community land is a subject-matter which is not recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Non-indigenous rural communities, through forming rural institutions, can formulate rural-forest management plans.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Scheduled Tribes and traditional forest dwellers are the legal authority over registered "forest lands". The law provides forest dwellers with the right to hold, protect, access, dispose of forest produce within the forest land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Federal legislation only provides for government and private ownership rights. The laws are silent on community land rights.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Law empowers Commissioner of Lands as administrator, unless community representatives incorporated. Constitutionally, communities to be lawful owner-managers of registered community lands but Community Land Bill not enacted and weak on this; likely to be amended.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Elected community councils have legal authority over allocation to households for agricultural & residential purposes. State guidelines with customary norms apply. Less direct mechanisms for authority over off-farm commons.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Ejido land is governed in accordance with the internal rules of the ejidos as long as the rules do not violate laws or regulations. However, the Ejido "general assemblies" are given legal authority to manage ejido land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Articles 17-24 of the 2002 Law on Land indicates that government bodies retain authority over land allocated under a possession contract, which indicates that communities do not have legal authority.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Subject to Ministerial direction, the Traditional Authority may authorise use & occupation of any customary land in accordance with customary law. Elected Local Government Assemblies also have some powers.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Vested in chiefs, who do have committees, not in communities per se. Tribal community in the person of chief has enormous authority.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Autonomy and freedom of the communities with respect to the use and free disposition of their lands. Communities' customary practices, traditions, and cultural identity are respected.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Indirect provision for a People's Administration to be created at quarter, village or tribal camp level by local government (Locality) and endowed with powers. Also titular provision for Native Administration but powers unstated.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Traditional Authority constitutionally recognized & part of local government system. Courts to apply customary law subject to Constitution and statute. Provision for local level institutions to be lawful land authorities in community land sector.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Day-to-day control of chiefs over land matters is high, including provision for elders advice and de facto community consensus.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Constitution supports customary law including traditional authorities powers but subject to limitations which include customs not permitted to be an obstacle to public action or laws.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Indigenous communities with community land use permits can only collectively manage and use state-owned land. The government retains legal authority over the land permitted to communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Elected village government (Village Council) is made legally responsible for management of all village land including allocations to parcels or other rights within Village Land Area.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Law provides for Parish Land Committees (village cluster level) but not elected by community, appointed & paid by District Council. Customary regulation & management to apply.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Traditional Authority (Chief) has lawful authority to govern customary lands under customary law although not a legal person. No requirement to govern inclusively. No provision for elected land committees.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: No legal powers of communities or traditional authorities at village level although hold significant duties and head advisory village assemblies. Real administrative power is vested in remote district councils and President as owner of Communal Lands.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Section 3 of the Act provides that "the Aland Parliament shall represent the people of the Aland Islands in matters relating to its autonomy. The Administration of Aland is vested in the Government of Aland and the officials subordinate to it."

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Agricultural communities function like decentralized corporations under public law and are therefore self-governing. The federal skeletal law grants agricultural authorities broad legal authority over agricultural community land. Not only can authorities determine which properties can be designated as community land, but Section 18 of the federal skeletal law states that agricultural authorities have discretion to approve sales and divisions of agricultural land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The national level law does not explicitly grant rural communities rights to community forests in Bulgaria. Control and management of community forests is vested in municipalities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of rural communities in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: State-level (cantonal) laws recognize community rights to "Group inherited" forests and common pastures (e.g. Canton Graub√ºnden). However, since LandMark's assessment is limited to national level laws, state-level laws are not assessed. There are no explicit provisions recognizing and protecting community land rights in federal laws.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Community members retain authority to use and enjoy the land and water for agricultural purposes; however, their authority is subject to overarching limitations established by the state. Authority over the agricultural community is also vested in Board of Directors and President of the Agricultural community (Art. 17-22, Law on Agricultural Communities) as opposed to the community members themselves.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Members of the collective retain legal authority over the collectively-owned land. Decisions on land contract schemes, utilization of land, etc. are subject to members of the collective. But collective authority is subject to overarching government approval.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Law provides for village land management committees to identify and record rights but these are not elected by community nor vested with powers other than delimitation of village territories and identification of rights for certification.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Traditional or elected land authorities not provided for but  under local government laws, Decree 2013-280 provides for community development committees at village level with significant powers including relating to land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: According to Article 19 of the Constitution of Cuba, agricultural cooperatives can sell, exchange, or transfer agricultural cooperative land, through another title, to the State and to other agricultural-livestock production cooperatives, or to small farmers, in the instances, forms and conditions that the law establishes without prejudice to the State's preferential right to its purchase, through payment of its fair price. Art. 20 of the Constitution provides "the agricultural-livestock production cooperatives administer, possess, use, and dispose of the assets of their property, in accordance with that established in the law and its regulations." However, the state retains broad authority over the management and use of agricultural cooperative land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture retains broad authority over forest lands in Germany. Afforestation, management, and protection of forest lands are regulated by government bodies.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Article 57(10) of the Constitution provides communities with the right to "create, develop and practice their own legal system or common laws, which cannot infringe constitutional rights, especially those of women, children and adolescents." However, this provision is not implemented through legislation or regulations.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: According to a secondary source (see comments box), some privately owned forests in Spain are held and managed collectively in practice. However, the national law on Forests (Law No. 43/2004) does not explicitly grant communities rights to forest lands.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Key responsibilities devolved to parish level land committees, including maintaining register of landholding certificates. District has supervising roles for instituted State Land Authorities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Section 3 of the Act provides that "the Aland Parliament shall represent the people of the Aland Islands in matters relating to its autonomy. The Administration of Aland is vested in the Government of Aland and the officials subordinate to it."

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: No institutional recognition of traditional authorities. Legal commitment to delimiting village domains with elected councils but not applied. Creation of community controlled forests provided for.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Customary law (recognized) vests fiduciary authority in unelected traditional authorities. State controls mineral, water & timber in customary lands. Administrator of Stool Lands has revenue collection & distribution powers.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Authority over customary lands is fully vested in traditional leaders (District chief and village heads). Not elected and no legal guidance on actions and report to President.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: CFMAs authorize community groups to occupy a specified area of State forest and manage that area in accordance with the CFMAs.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulator framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Hungary.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Collectives have legal authority, but for the specific purpose of carrying out agricultural activities. The Agrarian Reform Authority retains broad legal authority over collective farms. But collective farms can make contracts, settle disputes on collective farmland.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Communal land is not recognized in any of the Israeli laws assessed.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: National-level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous or local communities. However, collective property rights of rural communities in Northern Italy are recognized by state-level laws in Trentino.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Jamaica's statutory and regulatory frameworks do not recognize the land rights of the Maroons and has not accepted or rejected the treaty between the Maroons and Great Britain

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The state retains ownership over pastures. Communities are only given the right to use pastures assigned to their local self-government area within the provisions of the Community Pasture Management and Use Plan developed by the local governments.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Communites must follow a Community Forest Management Plan. The Forestry Adminstration has broad authority to determine details of the plan and to monitor community activities. Communities are not allowed to alienate, sell, form a concession or otherwise transfer its rights to third parties (Art. 44, Forestry Law).

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The level of legal authority varies depending on the land's classification and whether the community is granted a land use certificate, land survey certificate, or a land title.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Tribal authorities (now elected) have key role as administrators of customary norms. Approved Land Policy & Draft Land Rights Law looks to more inclusive community-based authority.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The Law does not recognize any right for tribes or clans to define and regulate their rights through institutional mechanisms rooted in the community. Land ownership is abolished, and the right to usufruct is granted in limited cases exclusive of tribal land, and subject, when given, to the national law.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Latvia.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights in Macedonia.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Traditional Authority and community courts are   recognized and customary land law operates but mimimal legal trend towards community governance over lands & resources or regulation to ensure inclusion and accountability.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: No provisions for governance, or limitations on customary law, rendering community members vulnerable to non-transparent decision-making by family or community heads.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The Constitution, Statute of the Autonomy of the Atlantic Cost, and Law 445 recognizes the legal authority and autonomy of indigenous populations in Nicaragua. Authority over and administration of the tenure regime is vested in the communal assemblies, territorial assemblies, traditional community authorities, and territorial authorities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Section 3-1 of the Act relating to bygd commons provides that "management of the bygd commons belongs to the commons board." Bylaws of the common board must be approved by the Ministry.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The Forest Act provides communities some authority over the forest area, but this is subject to the rights specified in the Work Plan. Communities have no authority beyond hat granted by the Work Plan.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Pakistan's statutory laws do not explicitly specify the extent to which communities have authority over lands held under customary tenure.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Authority over customary lands vested in incorporated land groups.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The national level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of local communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Article 5 of the Law on Baldios indicates that the customs of local communities determine how vacant land is used and enjoyed. However, the state has authority to develop use plans in cooperation with local communities (Art. 6-8). Also, land is administered by governing bodies (assembleia de compartes) as opposed to the community members themselves and a governing board (Art. 20).

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The Forest Code (2008) indicates that communities have some authority over how to use communities forests, but the government retains authority over the forest. Furthermore, it is not clear the communities have discretion to define and regulate their land rights through institutional mechanisms rooted in the community.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: No legal provision for traditional authorities or modern community bodies to exercise legal authority over local land matters other than assisting District Land Bureaus.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Mixed: authority legally vested in Traditional Authorities (Chiefs and Chiefdom Councils) but not fully elected and govern lands in accordance with unwritten customary law. Law allows District Councils to acquire and manage & survey areas for settlement or development.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Land associations have are corporate bodies with management bodies that have legal authority over the management of community forests. Land associations without legal personality are based on the free association of physical persons who are owners of shares of common property.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Communal land is not recognized in federal statute and there is no mechanism to legally affirm a parcel of land as such.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Local government authorities retain broad authority over pastures, including developing management and use plans which local communities (Pasture User Unions) must follow.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: There is no specific provision regarding the authority of communities over their land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The law indicates that villages can use pastures and rangelands for grazing and subsistence prupose. Villages can also utilize forest resources located on pasturelands. However, the Commission retains authority to allocate land areas and set limitations on grazing and other uses.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The law suggests the communities have limited authority over their lands and forests. Governments authorities at federal, state, municipal, and town levels are granted broad authority to dispose, transfer, withdraw, purchase land held by local communities (Arts. 9-12, 2001 Land Code). The government also retains authority to monitor community use and compliance with environmental legislation under the Land Code (Art. 12(f))

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Authority over community land is vested in representatives or heads of communities. The use rights granted to communities through state-issued certificates entitles holders to sell, rent, exchange, mortgage and exclude others from their land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Yemen is widely dependent on customary law (referred to as 'Urf'), especially in rural areas, for the allocation of land rights and mediation over water- and land-related disputes. This autonomous governing role, so prevalent in Yemen and carried out by locally acknowledged sheiks, are not reflected, and thus protected, in statute. Yemen's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Community Lands
note: Traditional Authorities have constitutional backing and since 2003 must establish councils with 40% elected members and one third women. No provision for elected land councils other than in CPAA 1996.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Rural communities defined as having collective rights to administration, and to operate according to principles of self-administration & governance.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Federal legislation, which grants indigenous communities legal authority over their land, has not been passed.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The High Court of Australia held that native title entitles indigenous inhabitants, in accordance with their laws or customs, to their traditional lands. Traditional customs must be observed on "substantially uninterrupted basis" to claim title. However, native title rights must generally give way to other rights and are inalienable except to the crown. Furthermore, the Native Title Act provides native title holders with a right to negotiate what can and cannot occur on their land, but these holders do not have veto power.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Authority over community lands devolved to communities who set up Village Land Commissions and also develop Local Land Charters specifying community agreed rules. Local commune supervision.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: PIOC, ICO, and PC have the authority to determine the distribution of their lands according to their own customary rules (so long as it is compatible with public law). They also have autonomy to govern themselves in every level of their organization.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution recognizes IPs social organization, customs, languages, creeds, and traditions. Free choice of livelihood and subsistence. Respect for the rules applied to ownership of land

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Village headmen & committees, elected district councils, Tribal Administration only have consultation roles, no decision-making powers. Boards not fully localised & undemocratic, also must comply with state directions.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: First Nations and other aboriginals have a right to self-government and may exercise management and control over their lands in native reserves, but this authority is subject to the Governor of Council's approval under Sec. 60 of the Indian Act.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous authorities are competent to govern their territories, to apply customary administrative and judiciary rules, to freely manage their natural resources, and to govern according to their internal regulations and social organization.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Local government communes may hold lands for communities or allocate use rights. Cooperatives have authority over allocated lands.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Mixed: legal land authority vested in Land Administration Bodies at provincial level l(zoba) but 699 village clusters elect governments and have de facto authority in vacuum of application.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous land rights are not explicitly recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The Forest Law states indigenous communities, if still existent, shall be allowed to manage their forests according to the prevailing indigenous law so long as it does not contravene state law.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Scheduled Tribes and traditional forest dwellers are the legal authority over registered "forest lands". The law provides forest dwellers with the right to hold, protect, access, dispose of forest produce within the forest land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Law empowers Commissioner of Lands as administrator, unless community representatives incorporated. Constitutionally, communities to be lawful owner-managers of registered community lands but Community Land Bill not enacted and weak on this; likely to be amended.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The law provides that the exercise of all ownership rights of the community shall be subject to the responsibility of the traditional authorities and mechanisms for decision-making of the community, according to their customs.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Elected community councils have legal authority over allocation to households for agricultural & residential purposes. State guidelines with customary norms apply. Less direct mechanisms for authority over off-farm commons.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The law grants the community the right to determine the use of its land, the division of separate portions, and other rules governing the land. However, management of the land is left up to the comunidad through a representative body.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Articles 17-24 of the 2002 Law on Land indicates that government bodies retain authority over land allocated under a possession contract, which indicates that communities do not have legal authority.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Subject to Ministerial direction, the Traditional Authority may authorise use & occupation of any customary land in accordance with customary law. Elected Local Government Assemblies also have some powers.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Federal legislation is silent on this issue, but the High Court suggested that indigenous communities have legal authority over their customary and ancestral land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Vested in chiefs, who do have committees, not in communities per se. Tribal community in the person of chief has enormous authority.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Autonomy and freedom of the communities with respect to the use and free disposition of their lands. Communities' customary practices, traditions, and cultural identity are respected.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Right to self-governance and self-determination explicitly recognized, including right to determine and decide priorities for development, and freely pursue own economic, social and cultural development. Customary systems compatible with Constitution and internationally-recognized human rights recognized and supported.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The laws do not establish that communities have legal authority over their land. (Federal Law No.82-FS) "On Guarantees" established the right to self-government for indigenous peoples, but was amended.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Indirect provision for a People's Administration to be created at quarter, village or tribal camp level by local government (Locality) and endowed with powers. Also titular provision for Native Administration but powers unstated.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Traditional Authority constitutionally recognized & part of local government system. Courts to apply customary law subject to Constitution and statute. Provision for local level institutions to be lawful land authorities in community land sector.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Day-to-day control of chiefs over land matters is high, including provision for elders advice and de facto community consensus.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Constitution supports customary law including traditional authorities powers but subject to limitations which include customs not permitted to be an obstacle to public action or laws.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous communities with community land use permits can only collectively manage and use state-owned land. The government retains legal authority over the land permitted to communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Elected village government (Village Council) is made legally responsible for management of all village land including allocations to parcels or other rights within Village Land Area.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Law provides for Parish Land Committees (village cluster level) but not elected by community, appointed & paid by District Council. Customary regulation & management to apply.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Native Americans are granted the power to regulate their internal and social relations and enforce civil/criminal laws against tribal members, but the government retains broad authority over Native American Reserves.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Traditional Authority (Chief) has lawful authority to govern customary lands under customary law although not a legal person. No requirement to govern inclusively. No provision for elected land committees.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: No legal powers of communities or traditional authorities at village level although hold significant duties and head advisory village assemblies. Real administrative power is vested in remote district councils and President as owner of Communal Lands.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Austria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Bulgaria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher found no evidence of indigenous community land in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Switzerland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Article 7 of Law 19253 provides "The State recognizes the right of indigenous peoples to maintain and develop their own cultural manifestations, in all that is not contrary to the morals, good customs and public order. The State has the duty to promote cultures Indians, which are part of the heritage of Chilean nation" (unofficial translation). However, the law grants the National Indigenous Development Corporation authority over indigenous land (Arts. 11, 13, 15 Law No. 19253).

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Members of the collective retain legal authority over the collectively-owned land. Decisions on land contract schemes, utilization of land, etc. are subject to members of the collective. But collective authority is subject to overarching government approval.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Law provides for village land management committees to identify and record rights but these are not elected by community nor vested with powers other than delimitation of village territories and identification of rights for certification.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The law of 2011 permits IP to exercise their customs and traditional institutions, to define their own land uses, and to exercise their right to develop their economic and social systems to secure subsistence.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Art. 4 of Law No. 6172 provides that indigenous populations have legal authority to govern their lands, but administration is through community board representatives. The National Commission on Indigenous Affairs (CONAI) retains underlying authority.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The law does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous peoples in Cuba.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Germany that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Article 57(10) of the Constitution provides communities with the right to "create, develop and practice their own legal system or common laws, which cannot infringe constitutional rights, especially those of women, children and adolescents." However, this provision is not implemented through legislation or regulations.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Spain that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Key responsibilities devolved to parish level land committees, including maintaining register of landholding certificates. District has supervising roles for instituted State Land Authorities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Finland's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize and protect the land rights of Sami populations in Finland.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: No institutional recognition of traditional authorities. Legal commitment to delimiting village domains with elected councils but not applied. Creation of community controlled forests provided for.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Customary law (recognized) vests fiduciary authority in unelected traditional authorities. State controls mineral, water & timber in customary lands. Administrator of Stool Lands has revenue collection & distribution powers.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Authority over customary lands is fully vested in traditional leaders (District chief and village heads). Not elected and no legal guidance on actions and report to President.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Authority over Amerindian Lands is vested in the Village Council. Any lease agreement or rules on how land will be used (e.g. forestry, mining, and other purposes) must comply with the Constitution, abide by relevant national laws, and must be approved by the Minister of Amerindian Affairs and the Amerindian village.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Article 100 of the 2004 Property law indicates that communities have the right to govern their lands held under a communal system, and that communities also have power to authorize leases to third parties.

Authority over and administration of the tenure regime is vested in the communal assemblies, territorial assemblies, traditional community authorities, and territorial authorities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The Sami Parliament has authority to issue guidelines on the use of community lands, but these guidelines must be approved by the Ministry. Sami land is administered through the Finnmark Estate.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The Forest Act provides communities some authority over the forest area, but this is subject to the rights specified in the Work Plan. Communities have no authority beyond hat granted by the Work Plan.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Maori communities retain authority over their customary and freehold lands; however, this authority is subject to certain restrictions imposed by the state.

note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

note: Pakistan's statutory laws do not explicitly specify the extent to which communities have authority over lands held under customary tenure.

note: Indigenous communities are granted legal authority to manage their lands according to customary norms and practices.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution and Indigenous Communities Statute grants indigenous communities legal authority over their lands (Art 64, Constitution; Art 3, Indigenous Communities Statute). Authority over the community is vested in the community leaders.

note: The law is explicit that Malays are the indigenous people of Singapore. Beyond that, however, little legal protection is specifically given to land rights.
