indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Slovakia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The Sami legal authority is granted, but subject to the limitation that the authority only applies to the Laponia World Heritage Site. Authority is also shared with other members of the Laponiatjuottjudus organization.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not recognize land rights held by indigenous or local communities.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Tajikistan that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: There is no specific provision regarding the authority of communities over their land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The law indicates that villages can use pastures and rangelands for grazing and subsistence prupose. Villages can also utilize forest resources located on pasturelands. However, the Commission retains authority to allocate land areas and set limitations on grazing and other uses.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Ukraine that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: The Law states that the community can govern itself and choose its own governance systems.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Authority over community land is vested in representatives or heads of communities. The use rights granted to communities through state-issued certificates entitles holders to sell, rent, exchange, mortgage and exclude others from their land.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Yemen is widely dependent on customary law (referred to as 'Urf'), especially in rural areas, for the allocation of land rights and mediation over water- and land-related disputes. This autonomous governing role, so prevalent in Yemen and carried out by locally acknowledged sheiks, are not reflected, and thus protected, in statute. Yemen's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights.

indicatorLabel: V - Legal Authority - Indigenous People
note: Traditional Authorities have constitutional backing and since 2003 must establish councils with 40% elected members and one third women. No provision for elected land councils other than in CPAA 1996.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: A right of customary useful domain cannot be extinguished unless land fails to be used or voluntarily vacated.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: As custom may dictate rules in Local Land Charters then may be in perpetuity. Certificates are transferable by succession and inter vivos.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: PIOC, ICO, and PC land's rights are vested in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Quilombo communities land title is granted in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The Board owns tribal land in perpetuity in trust for citizens, citizens hold use rights in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Community lands are  granted in perpetuity. They are non-transferable, inalienable,  and unseizable.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Law grants right of perpetual enjoyment in form of Certificates of Possession including to rangelands and alfa steppe but only for arable development.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Individual lifetime usufructs only, or leases with fixed terms & annual rent - but improvements to land heritable & transferrable.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Community land is a subject-matter which is not recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Although the law does not establish a specific limit, the nature of the exploitation right/business license implies that there is a durational limit on the license/right.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Once registered, the ownership right to forest land may be held in perpetuity. There are no durational limits established in the FRA 2006.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Federal legislation only provides for government and private ownership rights. The laws are silent on community land rights.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Not stated although customary rights upon which community title is based are capable of indefinite duration.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Allocations including where formalized as Certificate of Allocation is a lifetime usufruct but passes automatically to spouse, or nominated heir. Corporate entities hold by fixed or 'indefinite' period.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The Agrarian Law does not establish durational limits on land owned by ejidos.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The law establishes durational limits on possession contracts granted to communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The law views customary property interests as limited to heritable rights of 'use and occupation' as allocated by traditional authorities. Full ownership obtained only through extinction of customary right in favour of leasehold or freehold.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: By custom, rights in perpetuity, but registered as heritable lifetime usufructs.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Communities' land rights are vested in perpetuity by the Constitution and special laws for the different types of communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Unregistered rights have no standing as property interests but exist as permissive occupancy & use of Government property for as long as the land is utilised and not needed for public purpose.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Community title not specified but presumed as community does not have limited lifetime. Term of customary rights within community land depend upon what the custom is (customary law).

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Customary law provides for heritable usufructs of male household head, now female household heads included.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Customary use rights held in perpetuity through transmission to heirs but with no legal force as these are occupancy and use rights on state land only and can be cancelled at any time.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The indigenous community has to renew its Community Land Use Permit periodically within a time decided on a case-by-case basis by the government.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: A customary right of occupancy shall be presumed to be granted for an indefinite term, unless a grant of a customary right of occupancy specifies otherwise.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Customary rights stated in law as owned in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Customary rights of occupation and use considered of unfixed term, and automatically transmissible and heritable by heirs.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Permits to occupy Communal Land are heritable, may not be sold or leased. Customary law to be taken into account  as appropriate.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The law does not establish durational limits on the rights of those domiciled on the Aland Islands, which indicates that rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The federal skeletal law does not establish durational limits on the ownership rights of agricultural communities, which implies that such rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The national level law does not explicitly grant rural communities rights to community forests in Bulgaria. Control and management of community forests is vested in municipalities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of rural communities in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: State-level (cantonal) laws recognize community rights to "Group inherited" forests and common pastures (e.g. Canton Graub√ºnden). However, since LandMark's assessment is limited to national level laws, state-level laws are not assessed. There are no explicit provisions recognizing and protecting community land rights in federal laws.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Law No. 5 on Agricultural Communities does not establish durational limits, which suggests that community rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Under Art. 14 of the Land Administrative Law and Art. 126 of the Property Law, there is a time limit on the use rights to farmland, forest land, and grassland. Although these rights can be renewed, it is not an automatic renew.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Although the 1998 land law declares customary rights will be extinguished in 2019, in the interim the law and the Civil Code presume these to exist in perpetuity as heritable rights of occupancy and use. Property Titles are also of indefinite term unless they are leases.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Unclear in the law if customary rights are recognized as owned in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Decree No. 125, the Agrarian Reform Law, and the Constitution do not establish durational limits on the land rights held by agricultural cooperatives, which suggests that these rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The Federal Forest Act does not establish durational limits on the ownership rights held by forestry communities, which indicates that such rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The Constitution indicates that indigenous and community land rights have no durational limits and thus may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: According to a secondary source (see comments box), some privately owned forests in Spain are held and managed collectively in practice. However, the national law on Forests (Law No. 43/2004) does not explicitly grant communities rights to forest lands.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Rural holding rights of peasant farmers, semi-pastoralists and pastoralists have no time limit.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The law does not establish durational limits on the rights of those domiciled on the Aland Islands, which indicates that rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: No express stipulation for customary rights but may be assumed to be of indefinite term by their eligibility for grants of absolute ownership based on occupation and use. Leases, concessions and occupation permits have term limits.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Customary allodial and customary freehold rights are owned in perpetuity and registrable as such. Usufructs, which may also be held in perpetuity, are limited to 99 year terms at registration.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Customary rights are held in perpetuity  and statutes support customary rights as lawful. However, there is no legal provision for these rights to be registered. Registrable entitlements are 99 year leaseholds.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: CFMAs have durational limits and the rights expire upon the expiration, revocation, or surrender of a CFMA.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulator framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Hungary.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Article 2 recognizes that the "area of agricultural land possessed by a person Tapu authorized or granted under long lease." The use of the term long lease that these rights are not granted for an unlimited duration.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Communal land is not recognized in any of the Israeli laws assessed.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: National-level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous or local communities. However, collective property rights of rural communities in Northern Italy are recognized by state-level laws in Trentino.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Jamaica's statutory and regulatory frameworks do not recognize the land rights of the Maroons and has not accepted or rejected the treaty between the Maroons and Great Britain

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Article 2 provides "Community Pasture Management and Use Plan (CPMUP) - a plan, covering a period of 5 years, for management and use of state-owned pastures." Therefore, use rights to pastures may not be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The Law on Forestry establishes durational limits on Community Forestry Agreements. Article 42 of the Forestry Law states that Community Forest Agreements have a validity not to exceed 15 years. However, such agreements may be extended based on monitoring and evaluation.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Land use certificates are granted for three years, indicating that community use rights may not be held in perpetuity. However, communities can also claim land titles which appear to not have a durational limit.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Customary law provides for right in perpetuity not historically supported in issue of Aborigines Deeds but not yet explicitly entrenched in still unenacted Land Rights Law 2015.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: When their lands and wells were deemed state owned, tribes were allowed to continue utilizing undisputed lands and wells subject to conditions set in national law. Non-compliance could result in ending their use of the land, and reassigning to others. Tribes' right to usufruct was, however, made ineffective by later laws restricting the tight to usufruct to individuals and their own families.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Latvia.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights in Macedonia.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Rights of land use and benefit have no fixed term if acquired by communities through occupation, or for residential or family use.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Customary rights governed by customary law including inheritance norms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The law does not establish duration limits on the ownership rights of indigenous and ethnic communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The law grants bygd commoners with legal personality , but not for purposes of land ownership.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Under the Forest Regulation, 2051, community forest rights are durational in nature, and the District Forest Officer retains authority to cancel or extinguish Community Forests at any time.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands

note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to land.

note: Lawful to hold rights in perpetuity for so long as customary law upholds this. Non-natives to chiefdom cannot hold customary land other than by 50 year leases renewable up to 99 years.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands
note: The Law on Pastures establishes that the use rights granted to Pasture User Unions have durational limits.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Community Lands

note: The legislation does not specify the duration of the community rights, but it is implicit in the Civil Code.

note: The Law on pastures suggest that the grazing and use rights to pastures and rangelands are temporary in nature, though there are no clear durational limits set.

note: The Constitution indicates that indigenous and community land rights have no durational limits and thus may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Spain that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Rural holding rights of peasant farmers, semi-pastoralists and pastoralists have no time limit.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Finland's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize and protect the land rights of Sami populations in Finland.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: No express stipulation for customary rights but may be assumed to be of indefinite term by their eligibility for grants of absolute ownership based on occupation and use. Leases, concessions and occupation permits have term limits.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Customary allodial and customary freehold rights are owned in perpetuity and registrable as such. Usufructs, which may also be held in perpetuity, are limited to 99 year terms at registration.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Customary rights are held in perpetuity  and statutes support customary rights as lawful. However, there is no legal provision for these rights to be registered. Registrable entitlements are 99 year leaseholds.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Land titles to Amerindian lands are granted for an unlimited period of time (these rights are held in perpetuity).

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The 2004 Property Law does not establish durational limits on indigenous ownership rights to land, which suggests that rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Hungary that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory frameworks do not explicitly grant indigenous communities (Assyrians) land rights in Iraq

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Communal land is not recognized in any of the Israeli laws assessed.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Italy that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Land use certificates are granted for three years, indicating that community use rights may not be held in perpetuity. However, communities can also claim land titles which appear to not have a durational limit.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Customary law provides for right in perpetuity not historically supported in issue of Aborigines Deeds but not yet explicitly entrenched in still unenacted Land Rights Law 2015.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: When their lands and wells were deemed state owned, tribes were allowed to continue utilizing undisputed lands and wells subject to conditions set in national law. Non-compliance could result in ending their use of the land, and reassigning to others. Tribes' right to usufruct was, however, made ineffective by later laws restricting the tight to usufruct to individuals and their own families.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Latvia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Macedonia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Rights of land use and benefit have no fixed term if acquired by communities through occupation, or for residential or family use.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Customary rights governed by customary law including inheritance norms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The law does not establish duration limits on the ownership rights of indigenous and ethnic communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The Finnmark Act 2005 does not impose durational limits on the land rights of Sami Populations which indicates that rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Under the Forest Regulation, 2051, community forest rights are durational in nature, and the District Forest Officer retains authority to cancel or extinguish Community Forests at any time.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The TTWA act does not impose durational limits on the rights of Maoris to hold customary and freehold Moari land, which indicates that these rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Pakistan's statutory laws does not explicitly indicate whether community land rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: According to Art. 9 of Act No. 72 of 2008, the land title awarded to communities is indefinite, meaning community ownership rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The Land Act 1996 does not establish durational limits on customary ownership rights to land, which indicates that community rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Poland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Portugal that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The Indigenous Communities Statute does not establish durational limits, which suggest that indigenous community land rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Romania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Rights recognized only at registration, provided as extendable 99 year leases for rural land. Excludes traditional common lands.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The law is explicit that Malays are the indigenous people of Singapore. Beyond that, however, little legal protection is specifically given to land rights. In addition, the indigenous fishing communities of the Seletar (also know an the Orang Asli Laut) are not given formal legal recognition or protection.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Lawful to hold rights in perpetuity for so long as customary law upholds this. Non-natives to chiefdom cannot hold customary land other than by 50 year leases renewable up to 99 years.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Slovakia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: There is no explicit statutory or regulatory provision ensuring that Sami can hold their co-management right to the Laponia World Heritage Site in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not recognize land rights held by indigenous or local communities.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Tajikistan that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The legislation does not specify the duration of the community rights, but it is implicit in the Civil Code.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The Law on pastures suggest that the grazing and use rights to pastures and rangelands are temporary in nature, though there are no clear durational limits set.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Ukraine that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: There is no durational limit in the 2005 Constitution, which indicates that indigenous land rights may be held in perpetuity.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Communities may use agricultural land for a "long and stable term", but community land use rights are not granted for an unlimited duration.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: Yemen's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights.

indicatorLabel: VI - Perpetuity - Indigenous People
note: This is presumed in Interim Protect of Informal Land Rights & provided for groups under CPAA 1996

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Limited if any protection on untitled customary lands. Consultation not permission is required at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: No indication that consent required, only consultation.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Consultation regarding exploitation of non-renewable natural resources is mandatory. Expropriation based on precedence of biodiversity conservation or public interest in which case proper compensation is due.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: ILO 169 rules are applied to Quilombo communities for administrative and legislative measures applied by the government within community lands. Land rights are inalienable.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Opinions to be sought including in public and recorded but formal consent of villages, village clusters (wards) or their traditional leaders is not required. Aggrieved persons may appeal against decision.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: On March 3, 2011, Colombia's Constitutional Court issued a ruling "unconditionally" recognizing indigenous rights to free, prior, and informed consent.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: No provision for consent required other than consultation.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Compensation payable when state wants land including to lease to investors but no right to refuse.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Community land is a subject-matter which is not recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The Constitutional Court held that forest concessions by the State shall keep taking into account the rights of indigenous peoples. The State must consult with the public before expropriating land for a public purpose, but no consent requirement.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Depending on the acquisition project, 70-80% of affected families, including Scheduled Castes and traditional forest dwellers, must consent to land acquisitions. The procedures for gathering consent are not clearly established.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Federal legislation only provides for government and private ownership rights. The laws are silent on community land rights.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Consent for state acquisition of community land for public purposes is not required. Inquiry is only for purposes of hearing claims for compensation and which does not need to be paid prior to state possession of the land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: State may take 'unallocated' land after consultation with councils but no definition of allocated land and could easily make commons vulnerable. Public interest also very broad including  de facto private interests.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Ejido land may be acquired through expropriation for a public purpose, and the consent of the ejidos is not a prerequisite. Ejidos are entitled to compensation when their land is expropriated.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The Law on Allocation of Land to Mongolian Citizens for Ownership does not provide for a public consultation process when the government decides to acquire land for "special needs of the state."

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: No consent required for takings of land by state for public purposes including where 'it appears expedient to the Minister' to transform an area into private holdings extinguishing customary rights and jurisdiction. Chiefs do have authority over allocations of use & occupation rights and may defeat wrongful occupancy via Traditional Courts.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: As state owns all communal areas no compensation for other than 'improvements'. Explicitly excludes communal grazing land. Chief consults with communities prior to allocations of new customary rights or approval for Board to issue leaseholds.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Rules of free, prior and informed consent are applied accordingly to ILO 169 Convention. Expropriation only allowed by public interest and compensation according to value market. (Law 26505)

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Exploiters of mawaat (wasteland) by drilling water drilling, cultivation, building, etc. entitled to register usufruct. No local consent mechanisms but must not interfere with settlements.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Obligatory consultation  for public purpose acquisitions but failure to consent may be overridden.  Traditional Authority needs consensus before agreeing lease to outsider. 'Public purpose' includes commercial enterprises.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: No provision for consent outside of customary law when affects customary land, generally obtainable via consensus. Although trustee not owner King's prerogative over Swazi National Land extremely high.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: No consent required at public acquisition and minimal consultation, and compensation is only for developments on the land, but eviction can take place only after compensation paid.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The Immovable Property Expropriation Act does not require the government to consult or obtain consent from indigenous groups/communities prior to acquiring land in a compulsory manner.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: (a) While transfer for public purpose of Village to General or Reserved Land must have community consent if <250 ha, for larger areas, Minister must consider village views but may approve; (b) contradiction in laws on scope of General Land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Constitution and Land Acquisition Act do not require consent to land acquired for public purpose; may hear and consider objections. Compensation to be paid prior to taking of possession, and right of appeal provided.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Consultation with those affected and the consent of chief required before customary land under his aegis is alienated into leaseholds. Compulsory acquisition includes consultation requirements, right of appeal relating to value of compensation, but not consent.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Strong powers of compulsory acquisition by both State & Rural Councils without consent or consultation of affected communities required, along with strong powers to 'set aside' communal lands for multiple purposes loosely defined as helpful to development of area.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law dose not explicitly grant those domicile on the Aland Islands the right to give consent in an inclusive manner before land can be acquired by governments and other outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly recognize the rights of communities to give consent prior to acquisition by governments or outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The national level law does not explicitly grant rural communities rights to community forests in Bulgaria. Control and management of community forests is vested in municipalities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of rural communities in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: State-level (cantonal) laws recognize community rights to "Group inherited" forests and common pastures (e.g. Canton Graub√ºnden). However, since LandMark's assessment is limited to national level laws, state-level laws are not assessed. There are no explicit provisions recognizing and protecting community land rights in federal laws.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law is silent on whether agricultural communities have a right to give consent prior to acquisition by governments or outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The State can expropriate collectively-owned land for a public purpose, and does not need to consult or obtain consent from collective.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: State may allocate leases or concessions on unregistered community land without consent but does provide process of amicable agreement when challenged by customary occupants, but for which final decision lies with government.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Only indirectly: the law says that no new title can be issued without identification of customary rights.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly grant communities the right to given consent prior to acquisition by the government or outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly grant communities the right to give consent prior to acquisition by the government or outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Article 57(7) of the Constitution provides communities with the right "to free prior informed consultation, within a reasonable period of time, on the plans and programs for prospecting, producing and marketing nonrenewable resources located on their lands and which could have an environmental or cultural impact on them..." Presidential Decree 1247 (2012) establishes procedures for gathering the free, prior, and informed consent of communities prior to acquisition for hydrocarbon exploitation, but it is unclear whether this Decree applies when land is acquired for exploitation of other resources.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: According to a secondary source (see comments box), some privately owned forests in Spain are held and managed collectively in practice. However, the national law on Forests (Law No. 43/2004) does not explicitly grant communities rights to forest lands.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Mixed provisions, some States limit expropriation of registered Holding Rights. Federal Law on Expropriation makes no provision for consent. Creation of State and Protected Forests requires 'participation' of communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law dose not explicitly grant those domicile on the Aland Islands the right to give consent in an inclusive manner before land can be acquired by governments and other outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Opportunities provided to object to issue of ownership and other grants of land but community consent is not required for any allocation or for designation of lands for Protected Areas.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: While customary owners (registered or not) have right to appeal any matter to do with compulsory acquisition, no legal consent requirement or even consultation, prior to land taking.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Although customary laws may require consent of affected persons prior to approval of application for lease, no statutory provision for this. No consultation or consent required at compulsory acquisition but communities are closely involved in deciding on creation of Protected Areas.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The Forest Act does not explicitly state whether communities have the right to give consent prior to acquisition of land and resources by governments and others.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulator framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Hungary.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The ARL does not explicitly grant collective farms the right to give consent prior to acquisition of their land by governments or outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Communal land is not recognized in any of the Israeli laws assessed. Protection of property is a constitutional right in Israel, yet the right to own land is not protected, and the protection of land occupied is narrowly interpreted in a manner that excludes Bedouin populations.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: National-level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous or local communities. However, collective property rights of rural communities in Northern Italy are recognized by state-level laws in Trentino.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Jamaica's statutory and regulatory frameworks do not recognize the land rights of the Maroons and has not accepted or rejected the treaty between the Maroons and Great Britain

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not adequately recognize or protect indigenous or community land rights in Jordan.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly provide local community members of Pasture User Unions the right to give consent prior to acquisition by governments and outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly grant communities the right to give consent in an an inclusive manner prior to acquisition by the government or outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law is silent on whether communities must give consent prior to the acquisition of their land use right by governments and outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Mixed. No consent required for compulsory acquisition, concessions, designation of Protected Areas, or takings for urban expansion outside formally deeded lands or acknowledged community forestlands.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Land is deemed state owned, and others can have only a right to usufruct limited to registered holders. The state does not need the consent of anyone when deciding to use the land for public purposes including allocating to others.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law is silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Latvia.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights in Macedonia.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Threat level to community lands is high from host of resources. Consent not required but requirements to consult and consider opinions especially for losses due to economic projects enable degree of negotiation.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Governor may extinguish customary rights virtually at will for broadly defined purposes. No provisions for consent for land takings.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Law 445 requires consultation and negotiation with communities whenever the government grants a concession to a third party for the purpose of natural resource extraction. However, community consent is not a prerequisite to land acquisition by governments and others.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly grant Bygd commoners with the right to give consent prior to acquisition by governments or outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The District Forest Officer can extinguish community-held forests without consulting or obtaining consent from the community

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Pakistan's statutory laws do not explicitly indicate whether communities must give consent before an outside actor may acquire their lands.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The state must obtain the consent of Incorporated Land Groups when entering into Forest Management Agreements with private actors that involve that forests held by customary landowners.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The national level statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of local communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Article 29 of the Law on Baldios provides that wasteland can be expropriated for a public purpose or if the land is abandoned. There is no explicit right granted to communities to give consent in an inclusive manner if the government decides to acquire land in a compulsory manner.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly grant communities the right to give consent in an inclusive manner prior to acquisition by governments and others.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Local consultation required at compulsory acquisition for public purpose including to create State Protected Areas but decision lies with state agencies.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: No non-native to area may occupy chiefdom lands without consent of the TA. Legal basis for acquiring chiefdom lands for public purposes is opaque. National Forests created by leasing chiefdom lands for rent through agreement.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly grant community forest owners the right to give consent prior to acquisition by the government or outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Maintains more or less the favourable provisions towards landlords.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly grant local communities the right to give consent prior to acquisition by the government and outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not provide any ruling regarding consultation or consent of a community in case of a land acquisition process. The law does not stipulate consultation, consent or procedure for appeal in case of compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not establish that villages have a right to give consent in an inclusive manner prior to acquisition by outsiders and others.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly grant communities the right to give consent prior to acquisition by the government or outsiders.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: The Law on Land 2013 provides communities whose land is recovered or public purposes the right to be consulted on compensation, resettlement, and support. However, the government does not need to obtain the community's consent in order acquire community land use rights.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: Yemen's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Community Lands
note: IPILRA 1996 protects unregistered land rights from deprivation of land without consent, except when for public purpose.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Limited if any protection on untitled customary lands. Consultation not permission is required at compulsory acquisition.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: The State can expropriate collectively-owned land for a public purpose, and does not need to consult or obtain consent from indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: The Native Title (Prescribed Bodies Corporate) Regulations 1999 provides that body corporates holding native title rights must consult and obtain consent with holders of native title holders prior to making a decision affecting their livelihood. Furthermore, the Native Title Act provides native title holders with a right to negotiate what can and cannot occur on their land, but these holders do not have veto power.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: No indication that consent required, only consultation.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Consultation regarding exploitation of non-renewable natural resources is mandatory. Expropriation based on precedence of biodiversity conservation or public interest in which case proper compensation is due.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Congress authorizes exploitation of water and mineral resources in IP's lands. Communities will participate in hearings during the decision process. Compensation is due if displacement occurs. Agreements with outside actors are regulated.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Opinions to be sought including in public and recorded but formal  consent of villages, village clusters (wards) or their traditional leaders is not required. Aggrieved persons may appeal against decision.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: The Supreme Court held that, when expropriating Aboriginal-titled land for a public purpose, the government has a procedural duty to consult with the indigenous populations affected.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: On March 3, 2011, Colombia's Constitutional Court issued a ruling "unconditionally" recognizing indigenous rights to free, prior, and informed consent.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: No provision for consent required other than consultation.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Compensation payable when state wants land including to lease to investors but no right to refuse.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous land rights are not explicitly recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: The Constitutional Court held that forest concession by the State shall keep taking into account the rights of indigenous peoples. The State must consult with the public before expropriating land for a public purpose.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Depending on the acquisition project, 70-80% of affected families, including Scheduled Castes and traditional forest dwellers, must consent to land acquisitions. The procedures for gathering consent are not clearly established.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Consent for state acquisition of community land for public purposes is not required. Inquiry is only for purposes of hearing claims for compensation and which does not need to be paid prior to state possession of the land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: When the acquiring land, the government "Expropriation Committee" must arrange a public consultation with communities affected  by expropriation. However, the law does not require consent from communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: State may take 'unallocated' land after consultation with councils but no definition of allocated land and could easily make commons vulnerable. Public interest also very broad including  de facto private interests.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Comunidad land may be acquired through expropriation for a public purpose, and the consent of the comunidad is not a prerequisite. Ejidos are entitled to compensation when their land is expropriated.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: The Law on Allocation of Land to Mongolian Citizens for Ownership does not provide for a public consultation process when the government decides to acquire land for "special needs of the state."

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: No consent required for takings of land by state for public purposes including where 'it appears expedient to the Minister' to transform an area into private holdings extinguishing customary rights and jurisdiction. Chiefs do have authority over allocations of use & occupation rights and may defeat wrongful occupancy via Traditional Courts.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: The Land Acquisition Act 1960 permits the government to expropriate land for a public purpose and does not need to consult or obtain consent from indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: As state owns all communal areas no compensation for other than 'improvements'. Explicitly excludes communal grazing land. Chief consults with communities prior to allocations of new customary rights or approval for Board to issue leaseholds.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Rules of free, prior and informed consent are applied accordingly to ILO 169 Convention. Expropriation only allowed by public interest and compensation according to value market. (Law 26505)

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Free and prior informed consent (FPIC) explicitly provided. FPIC Includes right to give or withhold consent to a project or acquisition, government or private. ICC/IP community entitled to internal consensus building using its own traditional structures and processes.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Federal legislation does not explicitly grant communities the right to give consent prior to acquisition.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Exploiters of mawaat (wasteland) by drilling water drilling, cultivation, building, etc. entitled to register usufruct. No local consent mechanisms but must not interfere with settlements.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Obligatory consultation  for public purpose acquisitions but failure to consent may be overridden.  Traditional Authority needs consensus before agreeing lease to outsider. 'Public purpose' includes commercial enterprises.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: No provision for consent outside of customary law when affects customary land, generally obtainable via consensus. Although trustee not owner King's prerogative over Swazi National Land extremely high.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: No consent required at public acquisition and minimal consultation, and compensation is only for developments on the land, but eviction can take place only after compensation paid.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: The Immovable Property Expropriation Act does not require the government to consult or obtain consent from indigenous groups/communities prior to acquiring land in a compulsory manner.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: (a) While transfer for public purpose of Village to General or Reserved Land must have community consent if <250 ha, for larger areas, Minister must consider village views but may approve; (b) contradiction in laws on scope of General Land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Constitution and Land Acquisition Act do not require consent to land acquired for public purpose; may hear and consider objections. Compensation to be paid prior to taking of possession, and right of appeal provided.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Federal legislation permits the Secretary of the Interior to acquire lands, water rights, or surface rights to lands within existing Native American Reservations without obtaining consent or consulting Native Americans.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Consultation with those affected and the consent of chief required before customary land under his aegis is alienated into leaseholds. Compulsory acquisition includes consultation requirements, right of appeal relating to value of compensation, but not consent.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Strong powers of compulsory acquisition by both State & Rural Councils without consent or consultation of affected communities required, along with strong powers to 'set aside' communal lands for multiple purposes loosely defined as helpful to development of area.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Austria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Bulgaria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Researcher found no evidence of indigenous community land in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Belize's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community rights to land.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Switzerland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: There are limited rights to give to consent prior to acquisition, but it is clear that FPIC has not been fully recognized by Chile's national laws.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: The State can expropriate collectively-owned land for a public purpose, and does not need to consult or obtain consent from collective.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: State may allocate leases or concessions on unregistered community land without consent but does provide process of amicable agreement when challenged by customary occupants, but for which final decision lies with government.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: IP to be consulted before projects are formulated that will affect their lands and resources. This includes protected area developments.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Costa Rica has ratified ILO Convention 169- which grants indigenous rights to give consent prior to acquisition (Art. 16 (para.2) of ILO Convention 169)- but clear procedures for ensuring consent is gathered in an inclusive manner have not been enacted in Costa Rica.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: The law does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous peoples in Cuba.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Germany that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Article 57(7) of the Constitution provides communities with the right "to free prior informed consultation, within a reasonable period of time, on the plans and programs for prospecting, producing and marketing nonrenewable resources located on their lands and which could have an environmental or cultural impact on them..." Presidential Decree 1247 (2012) establishes procedures for gathering the free, prior, and informed consent of communities prior to acquisition for hydrocarbon exploitation, but it is unclear whether this Decree applies when land is acquired for exploitation of other resources.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Spain that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Mixed provisions, some States limit expropriation of registered Holding Rights. Federal Law on Expropriation makes no provision for consent. Creation of State and Protected Forests requires 'participation' of communities.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Finland's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize and protect the land rights of Sami populations in Finland.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Opportunities provided to object to issue of ownership and other grants of land but community consent is not required for any allocation or for designation of lands for Protected Areas.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
note: While customary owners (registered or not) have right to appeal any matter to do with compulsory acquisition, no legal consent requirement or even consultation, prior to land taking.

indicatorLabel: VII - Right to consent before land Acquisition - Indigenous People
