It is unclear what is these extent of these forestry rights and whether they extend to ownership of the trees on Maori land.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Pakistan's statutory laws do not explicitly specify whether communities are granted rights to trees.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Forestry laws stipulate that government agencies are to work in conjunction with the relevant indigenous communities when granting licences for forestry development in comarcas and indigenous territories.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: The Forestry Act 1991 recognizes community ownership rights to "forest produce" growing on customary lands. The state retains authority to grant leases, licenses, and concessions to trees on customary lands.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Poland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Portugal that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Paraguay's statutes and regulations do not explicitly recognize that indigenous community property includes rights to trees on the land.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Romania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Trees on registered land belong to the owner and who may use and manage in accordance with rules. Access and use to trees outside private lands requires permits.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to trees.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: The Seletar, or Orang Asli Laut, depend on mangroves but have no legal rights protecting and preserving their use of them.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Evidence that trees are owned is found in requirement of Traditional Authorities to compensate leaseholders for economic trees if end the lease. Community Forests common since 1988 Forestry Act.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Slovakia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: The Laponia Management plan covers all land and water areas within the Laponian World Heritage Site. Presumably, the Sami co-management rights extent to trees within the World Heritage Site. However, the law does not provide Sami with explicit rights to trees located outside the World Heritage Site.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Communal pastures and forests are mainly state controlled

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Tajikistan that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Turkmenistan's statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to trees

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: The law makes no reference about the property of the trees in community land. According to the Civil Code, the trees attached to the ground are considered part of the land. The Civil Code establishes the right of the owner of the land to plant trees, if not contrary to any other legislation (e.g., land use and environmental legislation).

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Article 28 of the Law on pastures provides that villages may use forest areas.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Ukraine that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in Uruguay.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: The law includes flora and fauna as part of the "indigenous habitat," but Art. 54 mentions natural resources owned by the State located in indigenous communities

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: The law establishes that forests can be assigned to village population communities.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Yemen does not have a national forest policy, nor laws governing forested areas.

indicatorLabel: VIII - Rights to trees - Indigenous People
note: Law is not explicit but implies that owners may use trees other than those declared protected species or protected areas.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: State owns all waters, bound to assure access & use to citizens & legal entities for rational needs and uses. However communities may lose rights to waterlands and waters due to land law.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water is a national resource belonging to society. Domestic use rights guaranteed. Pastoralists guaranteed water access. Local land charters allow communities to regulate ponds and local waters.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Quilombo communities have rights to water and the government has the duty to issue a legal title that allows the community to exercise their right.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water made appurtenant to land right, therefore owned for domestic purposes explicitly including watering stock. Free use of  'public water' which comprises, streams, rivers, lakes, pans, swamps & underground water not lawfully appropriated for use.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water resources belong to the State. However, communities can utilize water resources for their own traditional purposes and for subsistence.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Constitution declares all land, water and natural resources below and above surface belong to the state, citizens have lifetime usufructs to their land and free rights to water for non-commercial use.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Community land is a subject-matter which is not recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Water Law 7/2004 recognizes traditional communal rights on water resources so long as they actually exist and have been confirmed with local regional regualtions.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Article 4 of the Water Code provide that the state owns all water in Kazakhstan. All citizens of Kazakhstan are permited the right to use water under Article 22, so presumably communities, as citizens of Kazakhstan, are provided rights to use water. However, since communities do not have recognized rights to land in Kazakhstan, communal rights to water may be limited and subject to government discretion.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: All waters are owned by the nation collectively, vested in the state. Only domestic use, spring or storage on property is not subject to permit.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water belongs to the Basotho Nation in common. Domestic use governed by customary law and community councils supervise  water points. Non-domestic use governed by Water Resources Act, 2008.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Ownership of water is vested in the State. The Agrarian Law grants the ejidos community rights to use water located on or near their land.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Constitution provides that "the State may give for private ownership plots of land, except pastures and areas under public utilization and special use." Article 5 of the 2002 Law on Land states "the land other than that for pasture and common use...shall be owned only by citizens of Mongolia." Art. 54 of the 2002 Law on Land provides that "summer and autumn settlements and rangelands shall be allocated to baghs and hot ails and shall be used collectively. Winter and spring pastures shall be prevented from livestock grazing during summer and autumn, and shall be carefully protected with public efforts." The State retains ownership of pasturelands but may allocate possession contracts to non-indigenous communities. The law does not explicitly establish indigenous or local community rights to water. However, communities are entitled to use rights as citizens, and are free to use water for domestic purposes (Art. 8, The Mongolian Law on water and Mineral Water Use Fees (1995).

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Although attached to the land, water is vested in President, control vested in Minister. Domestic rights to use public water assured.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Free rights to use for domestic purposes. Domestic includes personal stock watering.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water resources belong to the Nation. However, customary rules are respected as well as their right to use water resources within their lands including commercial and sustenance purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: All water is public property. Under Islamic Sharia, customary law & formal enactments, communities have rights of access including for irrigation & stock watering. Permits variously required.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Land Act declares rivers, lakes, canals, haffirs, wetlands and other areas of water to be public land (owned collectively by nation) except for pools, streams, swamps or secondary rivers traditionally owned and managed by a community.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water is owned by the nation. Access for domestic purposes is obligatory.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: All land and water is state property with free use by lawful occupants and private owners assured for non-commercial use.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Constitution of Thailand grants all citizens the rights to use natural resources (Art. 25).   Therefore, communities, as citizens have a rights to use water. Since communities are only granted Community Land Use Permits to forest areas, it can be implied that community water rights are limited to such areas.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water belongs to the nation, vested in the President as trustee. Customary water rights are upheld as of equal status and effect to a granted water use rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water is vested in Government in trust for the people, who have a general right of use for domestic, fire fighting and garden irrigation, and may obtain additional specific rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water vested in President, no ownership possible, but domestic use prioritized and does not require permit. Customary practices to apply.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: All water vested in President and rights to water in Communal Lands are vested in Minister in charge of Communal Lands. Rights for domestic use assured.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Aland Parliament has authority over water law but it is unclear whether those domiciled on the Aland Islands have ownership rights to water.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Federal Water Act, 1959 grants all citizens the right to use water for domestic purposes. Futhermore private property owners have a right to dispose water on their property for domestic purposes, so community landowners are granted this right.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to water.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Federal Water Act, 1999 recognizes the right of all citizens to use water for domestic purposes, and protects private ownership of water located within the boundaries of landowner. However, since communities in Bulgaria are not granted ownership rights to their lands, they are also not granted ownership rights to water located within their land. Under federal law, communities only have rights as citizens to use water for domestic purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of rural communities in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Water Industry Act, 2001 implies that the government owns all water resources in Belize. Use of water requires a license under the Water Industry Act (sec. 61). The Water and Sewage Authority is in charge of issuing licenses and administration of water use.  The Carribean Court of Justice held that Mayan communities in Belize have rights to lands they have customarily use and occupied. It can be implied that this judgement also recognized that Mayans have rights to use water located on such lands. However, the Carribean Court of Justice judgment has not been implemented through national legislation or regulation.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Rights and the sustainable management of water resources are recognized, respected and protected, including PIOC's, ICO's and PC's customary practices of managements.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Publicly-owned water bodies include surface waters (rivers, streams, lakes) (Article 664 of the Civil Code). The Civil Code also provides that landowners have ownership rights to the springs and groundwater located on their property (Art. 704, Civil Code). Therefore community landowners of forest areas and common pastures have ownership rights to the forests and common pastures. State-level (cantonal) laws recognize community rights to "Group inherited" forests and common pastures (e.g. Canton Graub√ºnden). However, LandMark's assessment is limited to national level laws, state-level laws are not assessed. Nevetheless, the Civil Code demsontrates that federal laws recogniz ownership rights to water.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Law No. 5 of on Agricultural Communities 1968 (Amendd 1993) establishes rights to use water located on lands held by agricultural communities. However, the law suggests that these rights a can only be used for agricultural purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Chinese government owns all water resources. Collectives are only granted use rights. The Ministry of Water Resources is charged with allocating water entitlements on an annual basis.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water is the common property of the nation with use rights for all, including the right of communities to define waters for sacred uses, and rights of individuals and communities to regulate  water on their properties, but limitations on recognition of community lands reduce score.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Constitution and Law 9-2004 establish water as State property but guarantee domestic access.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Article 20 of the Constitution provides "the agricultural-livestock production cooperatives administer, possess, use, and dispose of the assets of their property, in accordance with that established in the law and its regulations." Decreto Ley No. 138, 1993 establishes rights to use groundwater based on allocation plans established by the government (Art. 4).

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Article 4 of the Water resources Act, 2009 provides landowners with ownership rights to non-flowing surface water and groundwater located on their property. Therefore, community forest owners in Germany retain ownership rights to non-flowing surface water and groundwater located on their property.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Law guarantees water for domestic and agricultural needs. All water belongs to the state (national domain). Unclear that rights exist outside  lands under certificates or titles or are free.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Water Resources Act 2014 has passed in Ecuador and reportedly limits the water rights of indigenous communities by privatizing these rights (reviewer could not find a copy of this legislation online).

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: According to a secondary source (see comments box), some privately owned forests in Spain are held and managed collectively in practice. However, the national law on Forests (Law No. 43/2004) does not explicitly grant communities rights to forest lands.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water belongs to Ethiopians in common and domestic use (free) takes priority. Permits required for non-traditional or commercial uses.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Aland Parliament has authority over water law but it is unclear whether those domiciled on the Aland Islands have ownership rights to water.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water is public State Property but communities may freely access for domestic use in accordance with customary norms. Scored 2 rather than 1 due to limitations in recognition of customary property.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Ownership and management of all waters is vested in President on behalf of citizens. Customary norms of non-commercial water use apply in customary lands subject to policies.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water is defined as 'land' and land may be owned by the state, by individuals or by district authorities (chiefs) in trust for communities in accordance with customary law. Use of all water irrespective of owners is regulated.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Amerindian water rights can be implied from the State Lands Act. Amerindian Communities are granted traditional water entitlements, which are defined as use rights that are recognized by custom. All communities, as citizens, can obtain use rights as citizens.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulator framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Hungary.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: India's states have exclusive power to regulate water supplies, irrigation canals, water storage, etc., but there is no explicit recognition of community water rights in federal legislation or regulations (e.g. The Inter-State River Water Disputes Act, 1956). The Supreme Court of India has interpreted the right to water as included as part of the right to life (Art. 21 of the Constitution). Therefore,  all citizens, including communities, of India have a recognized human right to access and use drinking water (though State retains ownership). Since community ownership is limited to forest lands, it can be implied that community rights to water are also limited to waters located on forest lands.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Agrarian Reform Law No. 117 suggests that collective farms have a right to use water located on their properties  for agricultural purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Israeli Water Law Act states that all the water resources in Israel are public property, and there is no private or communal ownership in water resources.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Act No. 36 on Water Resources, 1994 recognizes that all citizens of Italy have a right to use water for drinking and human consumption. Therefore, presumably communities, as citizens, are also granted use rights to water in Italy. However, since community land rights are only recognized at the state-level in Trentino, but it is unclear whether collective property rights to water are recognized in other parts of Italy.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Jamaica's statutory and regulatory frameworks do not recognize the land rights of the Maroons and has not accepted or rejected the treaty between the Maroons and Great Britain

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Water Authority Law establishes Jordan's water governance structure; however, it does not establish that citizens have rights to own or use water. The Constitution and other laws do not establish that citizens or communities have a right to water.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note:
The law does not recognize communities or indigenous peoples as owners of water
but does grant Pasture User Unions the right to use water for agricultural/pasture purposes. Article 4 of the Water Code, 2005 provides that all citizens have a right to use water. Presumably, Pasture User Unions, as citizens of Kyrgyzstan, are granted the right to use water.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Law on Water Resources Management provides that all water resources in Cambodia are owned by the state (art. 3). The law only grants landowners use rights to water for drinking, washing, bathing, and other domestic purposes (art. 11). The law also provides landowners and occupiers rights to collect and use rainwater and water flowing through their properties. Indigenous community landowners can exercise these rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water belongs to people of Laos, and the Government acts on behalf of the people to manage and allocate water use rights. Use and protection rights to wetland areas may be allocated to individuals or organizations. The Water and Water Resources Law, 1996 provides individual use rights to water, which can be exercised by all citizens (thus, as citizens of Laos, communities are also granted a use right). Community use of water for domestic purposes is free and does not require authorization.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water may be private or community property  (e.g. in forestlands) with its use closely regulated by statute.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water is public common property and may be freely used for domestic and stock watering purposes. In practice communal wells are possessed by tribes but without formal recognition.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Although Sri Lanka established the Water Resources Board Act, 1964, there currently is no national-level statute or regulation establishing legal rights to water. In pratice, Sri Lankans get their water supplied by the National Water Supply & Drainage Board, and communiies obtain water through customarily recognized practices, which are not protected by law.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize the land rights of local communities in Latvia.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize community land rights in Macedonia.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water belongs to the State. Distinction drawn between common and private use. Common use includes domestic & personal use including stock watering and small scale irrigation. Not subject to permits or fees, conducted locally in accordance with traditional norms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: While ownership is vested in government customary right holders may freely take & use water on land for domestic purposes, stock watering & personal irrigation.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Law 445 indicates that ownership rights to water are included within the bundle of communal property rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: With approval from the bygd commons board, fishing may take place within waterways in Bygd Commons. Communities, as citizens, can also use water for domestic purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Under the Water Resources Act, 2049 (1992) citizens are granted rights to use water for domestic pruposes, which means that communities are also granted the right to use water on an individual or collective basis. However, since community land use rights are limited to forest areas, it can be implied that water rights are limited to such areas as well.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The law states that all land in the country is the property of the state, unless specified otherwise. Government land plots are routinely granted on usufruct by the ministry for what are regarded as public utility or infrastructure projects. The Law permits Omani nationals to enjoy the benefits of owning land on freehold and leasehold bases. The owner of real estate property may lease it for residential or commercial purposes in Oman. A lease under Omani law does not provide any real rights in the property, but confers upon the lessee a leasehold right to occupy a land or a building. Pursuant to the Usufruct Law, usufruct rights over land are granted by the owner of the land to a third party for a consideration to utilize and develop it.' There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Pakistan has not enacted a comprehensive water statutory law at the national-level that defines property rights to water. Water belongs to the landowner under customary law, but LandMark assessment is limited to national level legislative and regulatory frameworks.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Customary rights to use water are recognized by the Water Resources Act, 1982. However, communitiy landowners are not given full ownership rights to water located on their land. Instead, the law provides only a right to use water for domestic purposes, fire fighting purposes, and recreational purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water is Poland is owned by the State, but citizens are graned rights to use water under the Water Law, 2001. Thus, communities, as citizens, have a right to use water in Poland. However, since community land rights are limited to forest areas, it can be implied that water rights are also limited to such areas.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Article 1 of the Law No. 54/2005 on the legal regime of water domain establishes that water in the public domain belongs to the state. However private property owners can obtain ownership rights to water located on their property (Law No. 54/2005 on the legal regime of water domain). Since communities have legal rights own and manage wastelands in Portugal, they presumably also have rights to own water resources located within these areas.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Although surface waters and their minor beds are owned by the public domain under article 3 of 1996 Water Law, the Law also provides that  land owners may own minor river beds. All citizens also have a right to use water for domestic purposes. Therefore, forest communities in Romania presumably have a right to own minor river beds and use water for domestic purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Water belongs to the State but access assured for domestic/farm livelihood uses without licences required.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to water.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: All water belongs to the State. Rights to use water descend from statute and customary law but without clarity beyond arrangements for piped water in towns.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The law does not explicitly grant communities rights to water located within community forest areas.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Syrian water law does not acknowledge communal ownership and management of water resources.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Law on Pastures suggests that Pasture User Unions local water sources for purposes of maintaining livestock (Art. 27 of Law on Pastures).

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Article 3 of the Water Code provides that all water bodies, including rivers, reservoirs, lakes, inter-farm canals and drainage collectors, ground water, as well as surface waters and water courses are property of the State. Article 4 indicates that ownership of water in Turkmenistan are exclusively held by the State. Individuals are granted rights to use water for drinking and household needs (Arts. 16-17, and 21 of the Water Code). Thus, communities, as citizens, can use water for domestic purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The law creates the category of 'community water', but gives no definition. The law leaves the regulation of community water to customary practices.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Communities, as citizens of Turkey, are granted rights to drink and use water for domestic purposes. Use rights to pastures and rangeland are granted to municipalities and villages. Thus, it can be implied that communities have rights to use water located on pastures and rangelands.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Article 59 of the Land Code recognizes that water rights may be granted to communities, but Article 6 of the Water Code of Ukraine that water is only available for use (not ownership).

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The state owns all water in the public domain (Art. 16, Water Code, 1978).  All citizens are granted rights to use water in the public domain if they register, so communities, as citizens, have a right to use public waters. (Art. 8, Water Code). The Water Code also recognizes that private property owners have rights to rain water and riverbeds located on their property. However, since national level statutory and regulatory laws do not grant communities land ownership rights, communities are also not granted the water rights granted that apply to privately owned land.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to Indigenous peoples and not non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The Constitution vests all land- including forests, rivers, lakes, water resources in the populations, but the state is empowered to manage land and allocate land use rights to communities -Article 4 of the Law on Land 2013). The State shall hand over land use rights to land users in accordance with this Law." Article 5 includes "communities" as a category of land users and defines communities as "Communities, including Vietnamese communities residing in the same village, street quarter or similar residential area sharing the same customs and practices or the same family line." Article 131(3) of the Law on Land 2013 provides that "Communities are allocated land or recognized land use rights by the State to preserve national identities associated with the traditions and customs of the people..." Under Article 1 of the 1998 Water Resources Act, communities, as citizens of Vietnam, are also granted rights to use water "for life and production"

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: All citizens of Yemen have a right to use water for drinking and household needs. Communities, as citizens of Yemen, have a right to use water to fulfill household or domestic needs (Section IV, Water Law of 2002).

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Community Lands
note: The National Government is the public trustee of all water and responsible for its protection and wise use. Persons have full rights to use domestically and acquire rights for other purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: State owns all waters, bound to assure access & use to citizens & legal entities for rational needs and uses. However communities may lose rights to waterlands and waters due to land law.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Native Title Act 1993 indicates that indigenous populations can file claims for native title to water resources, but the law does not specify the extent of indigenous water rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous peoples are entitled to the exclusive use of the rivers and lakes within their territory. Since the right is to exclusive use, but not ownership, a score of 2 is justified.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water made appurtenant to land right, therefore owned for domestic purposes explicitly including watering stock. Free use of  'public water' which comprises, streams,  rivers, lakes, pans, swamps & underground water not lawfully appropriated for use.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Federal Water Act, 1985 does not establish ownership or use rights to water for citizens; it only establishes Canada's water governance structure. Water rights are governed at the provincial level in Canada, and most provinces require a permits or licenses to use water. Communities, as citizens, have rights to safe drinking water under the Safe Drinking Water for First Nations Act

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water resources belong to the State. However, communities can utilize water resources for their own traditional purposes and for subsistence.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Constitution declares all land, water and natural resources below and above surface belong to the state, citizens have lifetime usufructs to their land and free rights to water for non-commercial use.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Indigenous land rights are not explicitly recognized by Greenlandic law.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Water Law 7/2004 recognizes traditional communal rights on water resources so long as they actually exist and have been confirmed with local regional regualtions.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Not applicable: National legislation applies only to non-indigenous communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: All waters are owned by the nation collectively, vested in the state. Only domestic use, spring or storage on property is not subject to permit.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Law on Water Resources Management provides that all water resources in Cambodia are owned by the state (art. 3). The law only grants landowners use rights to water for drinking, washing, bathing, and other domestic purposes (art. 11). The law also provides landowners and occupiers rights to collect and use rainwater and water flowing through their properties. Indigenous community landowners can exercise these rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water belongs to the Basotho Nation in common. Domestic use governed by customary law and community councils supervise  water points. Non-domestic use governed by Water Resources Act, 2008.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Ownership of water is vested in the State. The Agrarian Law grants ejidos/ comunidades rights to use water located on or near their land.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution provides that "the State may give for private ownership plots of land, except pastures and areas under public utilization and special use." Article 5 of the 2002 Law on Land states "the land other than that for pasture and common use...shall be owned only by citizens of Mongolia." Art. 54 of the 2002 Law on Land provides that "summer and autumn settlements and rangelands shall be allocated to baghs and hot ails and shall be used collectively. Winter and spring pastures shall be prevented from livestock grazing during summer and autumn, and shall be carefully protected with public efforts." The State retains ownership of pasturelands but may allocate possession contracts to non-indigenous communities. The law does not explicitly establish indigenous or local community rights to water. However, communities are entitled to use rights as citizens, and are free to use water for domestic purposes (Art. 8, The Mongolian Law on water and Mineral Water Use Fees (1995).

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Although attached to the land, water is vested in President, control vested in Minister. Domestic rights to use public water assured.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The  Water Act, 1920 and the Water Services Industry Act, 2006 do not establish that individuals have a right to use water for domestic purposes. The Act only provides that ownership and control of rivers in each State are vested solely in the Ruler of such State (Sec. 3). Presumably, water resource governance is established at the state-level, but LandMark's legal indicator assessment is limited to national-level laws. Obstructon or interference with Malaysia's rivers requires a license (sec. 5, Waters Act, 1920).

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Free rights to use for domestic purposes. Domestic includes personal stock watering.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water resources belong to the Nation. However, customary rules are respected as well as their right to use water resources within their lands including commercial and sustenance purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Definition of ancestral domain explicitly includes bodies of water, including inland waters and coastal waters within its boundaries. But the provision on natural resources exploitation and development within ancestral domains is ambiguous, merely granting priority rights to ICCs/IPs.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Water Code of Russia, 2008 provides state ownership of surface waters and public water bodies (art. 6). However, article 6 further provides that "everyone person has the right of access to public waer bodies and can use them free of charge for personal and domestic needs..." Based on this provision, it can be presumed that indigenous communities in Russia have a right to use water for domestic purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: All water is public property. Under Islamic Sharia, customary law & formal enactments, communities have rights of access including for irrigation & stock watering. Permits variously required.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Land Act declares rivers, lakes, canals, haffirs, wetlands and other areas of water to be public land (owned collectively by nation) except for pools, streams, swamps or secondary rivers traditionally owned and managed by a community.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water is owned by the nation. Access for domestic purposes is obligatory.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: All land and water is state property with free use by lawful occupants and private owners assured for non-commercial use.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution of Thailand grants all citizens the rights to use natural resources (Art. 25).   Therefore, communities, as citizens have a rights to use water. Since communities are only granted Community Land Use Permits to forest areas, it can be implied that community water rights are limited to such areas.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water belongs to the nation, vested in the President as trustee. Customary water rights are upheld as of equal status and effect to a granted water use rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water is vested in Government in trust for the people, who have a general right of use for domestic, fire fighting and garden irrigation, and may obtain additional specific rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Supreme Court held that water rights are defined by Congress, but when American Indian reservations are established by treaty, statute or executive order, implied reservation of water rights is included.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water vested in President, no ownership possible, but domestic use prioritized and does not require permit. Customary practices to apply.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: All water vested in President and rights to water in Communal Lands are vested in Minister in charge of Communal Lands. Rights for domestic use assured.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Civil Code grants all citizens the right to use and enjoy water resources within the country. This means that communities are granted the right to use water. Private land owners are granted ownership rights to water located on their land. However, since national laws do not granted communities ownership rights to their lands land, communities presumably do not have ownership rights (only use rights) to water located on their land.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Austria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Belgium that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water is a national resource belonging to society. Domestic use rights guaranteed. Pastoralists guaranteed water access. Local land charters allow communities to regulate ponds and local waters.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Statutory laws are silent on whether communities have legal rights to water.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Bulgaria that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher found no evidence of indigenous community land in Belarus.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Water Industry Act, 2001 implies that the government owns all water resources in Belize. Use of water requires a license under the Water Industry Act (sec. 61). The Water and Sewage Authority is in charge of issuing licenses and administration of water use.  The Carribean Court of Justice held that Mayan communities in Belize have rights to lands they have customarily use and occupied. It can be implied that this judgement also recognized that Mayans have rights to use water located on such lands. However, the Carribean Court of Justice judgment has not been implemented through national legislation or regulation.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Rights and the sustainable management of water resources are recognized, respected and protected, including PIOC's, ICO's and PC's customary practices of managements.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Switzerland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Articles 20-22 of Law No. 19253 establishes a Fund of Indigenous Land and Water, which suggests that indigenous communities obtain some rights to the water located within their lands. However, it is unclear whether indigenous communities have full ownership rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Chinese government owns all water resources. Collectives are only granted use rights. The Ministry of Water Resources is charged with allocating water entitlements on an annual basis.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water is the common property of the nation with use rights for all, including the right of communities to define waters for sacred uses, and rights of individuals and communities to regulate  water on their properties, but limitations on recognition of community lands reduce score.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water owned by the state. Constitution guarantees right to water as needed. Water Code drafted in 2010; enactment status unclear.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Law No. 6172 provides that indigenous communities are the owners of land held within their territories (Art. 2), and Article 4 of the Water Act No. 276 (1942) provides that landowners own water located within their property.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The law does not explicitly recognize the land rights of indigenous peoples in Cuba.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Czech Republic that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Germany that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Denmark that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Law guarantees water for domestic and agricultural needs. All water belongs to the state (national domain). Unclear that rights exist outside  lands under certificates or titles or are free.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Water Resources Act 2014 has passed in Ecuador and reportedly limits the water rights of indigenous communities by privatizing these rights (reviewer could not find a copy of this legislation online).

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Spain that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Estonia that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water belongs to Ethiopians in common and domestic use (free) takes priority. Permits required for non-traditional or commercial uses.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Finland's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly recognize and protect the water rights of Sami populations in Finland.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water is public State Property but communities may freely access for domestic use in accordance with customary norms. Scored 2 rather than 1 due to limitations in recognition of customary property.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the United Kingdom-England that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Ownership and management of all waters is vested in President on behalf of citizens. Customary norms of non-commercial water use apply in customary lands subject to policies.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water is defined as 'land' and land may be owned by the state, by individuals or by district authorities (chiefs) in trust for communities in accordance with customary law. Use of all water irrespective of owners is regulated.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory framework does not recognize the land rights of indigenous and local communities in French Guiana.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Amerindian water rights can be implied from the State Lands Act. Amerindian Communities are granted traditional water entitlements, which are defined as use rights that are recognized by custom. All communities, as citizens, can obtain use rights as citizens.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Under the General Water Law (2009), rights to both surface and groundwater vest in the state, but provides a right for all citizens to use water for domestic purposes. Under the Water Framework Law of 2003, municipalities have preference over all other users for the purpose of providing water for human consumption or discharge of sewage.  Indigenous communities, as citizens, have rights to use water for domestic purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Hungary that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: India's states have exclusive power to regulate water supplies, irrigation canals, water storage, etc., but there is no explicit recognition of community water rights in federal legislation or regulations (e.g. The Inter-State River Water Disputes Act, 1956). The Supreme Court of India has interpreted the right to water as included as part of the right to life (Art. 21 of the Constitution). Therefore,  all citizens, including communities, of India have a recognized human right to access and use drinking water (though State retains ownership). Since community ownership is limited to forest lands, it can be implied that community rights to water are also limited to waters located on forest lands.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Ireland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory frameworks do not explicitly grant indigenous communities (Assyrians) land rights in Iraq

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Iceland that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Israeli Water Law Act states that all the water resources in Israel are public property, and there is no private or communal ownership in water resources.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Italy that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: N/A

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Water Authority Law establishes Jordan's water governance structure; however, it does not establish that citizens have rights to own or use water. The Constitution and other laws do not establish that citizens or communities have a right to water.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water belongs to people of Laos, and the Government acts on behalf of the people to manage and allocate water use rights. Use and protection rights to wetland areas may be allocated to individuals or organizations. The Water and Water Resources Law, 1996 provides individual use rights to water, which can be exercised by all citizens (thus, as citizens of Laos, communities are also granted a use right). Community use of water for domestic purposes is free and does not require authorization.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water may be private or community property  (e.g. in forestlands) with its use closely regulated by statute.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water is public common property and may be freely used for domestic and stock watering purposes. In practice communal wells are possessed by tribes but without formal recognition.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Although Sri Lanka established the Water Resources Board Act, 1964, there currently is no national-level statute or regulation establishing legal rights to water. In pratice, Sri Lankans get their water supplied by the National Water Supply & Drainage Board, and communiies obtain water through customarily recognized practices, which are not protected by law.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in Lithuania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Latvia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Macedonia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Myanmar has not yet enacted a law that recognizes community or indigenous land rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water belongs to the State. Distinction drawn between common and private use. Common use includes domestic & personal use including stock watering and small scale irrigation. Not subject to permits or fees, conducted locally in accordance with traditional norms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: While ownership is vested in government customary right holders may freely take & use water on land for domestic purposes, stock watering & personal irrigation.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Law 445 indicates that ownership rights to water are included within the bundle of communal property rights.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" or "community" land in the Netherlands that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The same legal protections that apply to land also apply to water. Sami can use watercourse for fishing and other domestic purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Under the Water Resources Act, 2049 (1992) citizens are granted rights to use water for domestic pruposes, which means that communities are also granted the right to use water on an individual or collective basis. However, since community land use rights are limited to forest areas, it can be implied that water rights are limited to such areas as well.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Marine and Coastal Area (Takutai Moana) Act 2011 recognizes customary titles to the foreshore and seabed held by the Maori, but Moari have to apply to the Maori land court to achieve legal recognition.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The law states that all land in the country is the property of the state, unless specified otherwise. Government land plots are routinely granted on usufruct by the ministry for what are regarded as public utility or infrastructure projects. The Law permits Omani nationals to enjoy the benefits of owning land on freehold and leasehold bases. The owner of real estate property may lease it for residential or commercial purposes in Oman. A lease under Omani law does not provide any real rights in the property, but confers upon the lessee a leasehold right to occupy a land or a building. Pursuant to the Usufruct Law, usufruct rights over land are granted by the owner of the land to a third party for a consideration to utilize and develop it.' There is no explicit legal recognition of land rights held by indigenous peoples and local communities in  Oman

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Pakistan has not enacted a comprehensive water statutory law at the national-level that defines property rights to water. Water belongs to the landowner under customary law, but LandMark assessment is limited to national level legislative and regulatory frameworks.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: In 2012, the Government enacted Act No. 11 of 26 March 2012 which allowed the Ngobe-Bugle comarca indigenous communities to manage mineral, water, and environmental resources. But its unclear whether other communities have ownership or use rights to water located on their lands.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Customary rights to use water are recognized by the Water Resources Act, 1982. However, communitiy landowners are not given full ownership rights to water located on their land. Instead, the law provides only a right to use water for domestic purposes, fire fighting purposes, and recreational purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Poland that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Portugal that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Article 3 of Ley No. 3.239/07 (Water Resources Law) provides that "the waters, surface and ground, are owned by the public domain and its domain is inalienable and imprescriptible. The Water Resources Law grants all citizens the right use and drink water to fulfill their daily needs and for household/domestic purposes (Arts. 13, 15, 16). Therefore, it can be implied that community landowners, as citizens of Paraguay, have rights to use water for basic needs.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Reviewer could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Romania that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Water belongs to the State but access assured for domestic/farm livelihood uses without licences required.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Saudi Arabia's statutory and regulatory framework does not explicitly grant communities rights to water.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Seletar, or Orang Asli Laut, depend on mangroves but have no legal rights protecting and preserving their use of them.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: All water belongs to the State. Rights to use water descend from statute and customary law but without clarity beyond arrangements for piped water in towns.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Suriname does not have a statutory or regulatory framework that recognizes the land rights of Indigenous Peoples and local communities.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Slovakia that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Laponia Management plan covers all land and water areas within the Laponian World Heritage Site. Presumably, the Sami co-management rights extent to water areas within the World Heritage Site However, the law does not provide Sami with explicit rights to water located outside the World Heritage Site.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Syrian water law does not acknowledge communal ownership and management of water resources.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Researcher could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Tajikistan that falls within LandMark's definition of this term.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Article 3 of the Water Code provides that all water bodies, including rivers, reservoirs, lakes, inter-farm canals and drainage collectors, ground water, as well as surface waters and water courses are property of the State. Article 4 indicates that ownership of water in Turkmenistan are exclusively held by the State. Individuals are granted rights to use water for drinking and household needs (Arts. 16-17, and 21 of the Water Code). Thus, communities, as citizens, can use water for domestic purposes.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The law creates the category of 'community water', but gives no definition. The law leaves the regulation of community water to customary practices.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Communities, as citizens of Turkey, are granted rights to drink and use water for domestic purposes. Use rights to pastures and rangeland are granted to municipalities and villages. Thus, it can be implied that communities have rights to use water located on pastures and rangelands.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: Research could not find evidence of "indigenous" land in Ukraine that falls within LandMark's definition of these terms.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The state owns all water in the public domain (Art. 16, Water Code, 1978).  All citizens are granted rights to use water in the public domain if they register, so communities, as citizens, have a right to use public waters. (Art. 8, Water Code). The Water Code also recognizes that private property owners have rights to rain water and riverbeds located on their property. However, since national level statutory and regulatory laws do not grant communities land ownership rights, communities are also not granted the water rights granted that apply to privately owned land.

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The statutory and regulatory legal framework does not explicitly recognize the rights of indigenous and local communities in Uzbekistan

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The law includes water as part of the "indigenous habitat," but Art. 54 mentions natural resources owned by the State located in indigenous communities

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The Constitution vests all land- including forests, rivers, lakes, water resources in the populations, but the state is empowered to manage land and allocate land use rights to communities -Article 4 of the Law on Land 2013). The State shall hand over land use rights to land users in accordance with this Law." Article 5 includes "communities" as a category of land users and defines communities as "Communities, including Vietnamese communities residing in the same village, street quarter or similar residential area sharing the same customs and practices or the same family line." Article 131(3) of the Law on Land 2013 provides that "Communities are allocated land or recognized land use rights by the State to preserve national identities associated with the traditions and customs of the people..." Under Article 1 of the 1998 Water Resources Act, communities, as citizens of Vietnam, are also granted rights to use water "for life and production"

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: All citizens of Yemen have a right to use water for drinking and household needs. Communities, as citizens of Yemen, have a right to use water to fulfill household or domestic needs (Section IV, Water Law of 2002).

indicatorLabel: IX - Rights to water - Indigenous People
note: The National Government is the public trustee of all water and responsible for its protection and wise use. Persons have full rights to use domestically and acquire rights for other purposes.
